loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace produces and sells bottled water at both wholesale and retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. She hopes for a loan amount of 120,000 NGN to purchase more materials for producing more bottled water to sell. She is married with children. She hopes to expand her business. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for bottled water production

loans.name: Urinova Bahtigul's Group

texts.en:
U. Bahtigul is 41 years old. She is the leader of this group. Her husband is a builder. She has four sons. The eldest son works with his father, and the second oldest son is in Russia. The other sons study at school. She is involved in the cattle fatting business. She currently has one calf and one milk cow. She also produces milk products and sells them in Aravan. This loan will be used to buy one milk cow with calf in order to increase milk production. In the future, she hopes to open a big farm.

Hamid, age 40, is divorced. He has three grown sons, and all of them help him with agriculture. He has one hectare of land on which he cultivates cotton. He has been involved in this since 1996. This loan will allow him to buy cotton seeds and mineral fertilizer.

Haticha is 42 years old. She is a married woman with five children. Her husband is a builder and electrician. Usually, the building season opens in spring and continues until late autumn. In winter, her husband is usually at home, looking after the household. This loan will be used to buy cement, lime, and paint in order to repair their house.

Adinahan is 22 years old and is not married yet. She lives with her parents. Her father is a tractor driver, and her mother is a housewife. They have a little household where they fatten cattle. This loan will be used to buy four sheep. She is now preparing for a wedding and buying dowry for herself.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy one milk cow with calf

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To restock her stationery and secretarial bureau with more goods like duplicating papers, books, and pens

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expanding merchandise selection

loans.name: Saron

texts.en: Mrs. Saron N., a resident of Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province, is a 46-year-old farmer who owns 1.5-hectares of land upon which she cultivates rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Orouk Choun, is a fisherman. The rice field is currently infertile, far from the irrigation system, and is beset with many insects, so Mrs. Saron N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, fuel, and pesticide, and to hire laborers to plow the field. This couple has four children, two of whom are waitresses, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, fuel, pesticide

loans.name: Astou

texts.fr: Madame Astou S. est une commerçante vivant avec son mari, son enfant de 28 ans et ses neveux dans  la ville de Diourbel située à 150 Kms de Dakar la capitale du Sénégal, le pays de la téranga (hospitalité). Cette femme âgée de 48 ans fait le commerce des pagnes et de perles très suivi dans  toute la ville.  Elle l’a embrassé depuis plus de 20 ans  pour bien s’entretenir.Adhérant à U-IMCEC au niveau de la caisse de Ndayane Diourbel, Madame S. souhaitait bénéficier des crédits de la caisse. Ainsi, elle demande un financement de 200 000 FCFA pour s’approvisionner en pagne destinée à la revente.
texts.en:
Ms Astou S., a storekeeper, lives with her husband, her 28-year-old child and her nephews in the city of Diourbel, located 150 kilometers from Dakar, the capital of Senegal, in the land of téranga (hospitality). This lady, aged 48, trades in pagnes (a colorful West African wax cloth) and beads. Her products are in high demand in the city. She started this business over 20 years ago to provide for herself. Ms Astou is a member of the Ndayane Diourbel branch of the microfinance institution U-IMCEC, since she wants to benefit from loans. She applies now for a loan of 200,000 CFA francs to stock up with pagnes for resale.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock up with pagnes

loans.name: Mukim

texts.ru: Сафаров Муким проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 34 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Сафаров Муким имеет среднее образование. Торговлей занимается более 6 лет. Он продает продукты питания. В этом ему помогает жена. Муким привозит продукты из города Душанбе. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Mukim S. lives in the Vahdat district. He is 34 years, old, married and has 4 children. Mukim has a secondary education. He has been involved in retail sales for over 6 years. He sells food products with the help of his wife. Mukim brings in the products from the city of Dushanbe. He is requesting the loan in order to increase product turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Pach

texts.en: Mrs. Pach Y., who lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province, is a 46-year-old widowed farmer who owns 1.6-hectares of land upon which she  cultivates rice to support her family. She is the mother of four children, one a laborer, two fishermen, and one who is too young to go to school or work. The rice field is currently infertile, far from the irrigation system, and beset with insects, so Mrs. Pach Y. is requesting a a loan to buy fertilizer, fuel, and pesticide, and to hire laborers to plow her rice field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, fuel, pesticide

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Madame Coumba D. âgée de 43 ans s’active depuis 10 ans dans la vente de céréales. Elle est mariée mère de 4 enfants dont le plus âgé a 16 ans.  Elle vit avec eux et compte sur son commerce pour compléter les dépenses quotidiennes. Cependant, elle sollicite un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour le renforcement de son travail. Elle veut acheter avec ce financement  des céréales qu’elle entend commercialiser dans  Diourbel, une ville située à 150 Kms de Dakar la capitale du Sénégal.
texts.en:
Ms. Coumba D., aged 43, has been active for ten years in selling grains. She is married and the mother of four children; the eldest is 16 years old. She lives with them and counts on her business for meeting day-to-day expenses. However, she's requesting a loan of 100,000 francs CFA to bolster her work. She wants to use this loan to buy some grain, which she intends to sell in Diourbel, a city located 150 km from Dakar, the capital of Sénégal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Penda

texts.fr:
Madame Penda F. fait du commerce des pagnes et des perles pour les femmes. Elle a atterri dans ce secteur par l’influence de ses parents qui faisaient le commerce. Membre d’U-IMCEC depuis 2 ans, Madame F. est à sa troisième demande de crédit pour mieux développer son activité. Cependant, elle demande un financement de 150 000 FCFA pour l’achat de pagnes et de perles qu’elle entend commercialiser dans les marchés hebdomadaires.  
Célibataire sans enfant s, Madame F. âgée de 38 ans s’investit dans la vente pour mieux subvenir à ses besoins et de trouver une certaine indépendance.
texts.en:
Ms. Penda F. does commerce in pagnes (colorful West African cloth) and in pearls for women.  She settled upon this sector due to the influence of her parents, who used to work in commerce.  A member of U-IMCEC for two years, she is on her third loan request for developing her business further.  However, she is asking for financing in the amount of 150,000 francs CFA to buy pagnes and some pearls, which she intends to sell at the weekly markets.  Ms. F., aged 38, is single with no children.  She invests herself in selling in order do better in providing for her needs and to achieve some independence.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth and pearls

loans.name: Kigarama Women's Cooperative Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
S. Mariat is 31 years old and married with three children. She also takes care of five dependents.

Mariat is a hardworking and friendly lady with a strong drive to succeed. She has been involved in the sale of produce at Kigarama trading center for ten years and she is grateful that she has always been able to earn profits that enable her take care of her children.

Mariat’s business location is strategic and she hopes to expand her business further and educate her children to the highest level. She needs a loan to be able to buy more produce to sell so that she can generate more profits.

loans.use: To buy more produce to sell

loans.name: Ndeye

texts.en:
Ms. Ndeye S., aged 37, works with her mother selling fabrics - a very common business among women in Senegal. With her loan of 150,000 Francs, she will purchase “pairlarge” fabrics. With the income from her trade, she will be able to pay for the school fees of her 19-year-old son.

Ms. S. lives in the Keur Cheikh neighborhood of Diourbel, a small city about 150 km east from Dakar, Senegal's capital. The city is home to about 100,000 inhabitants, and shares its name with the larger Diourbel region which, before colonization, was known as the Bawol Kingdom. Diourbel's inhabitants are still often called Bawol-Bawol.

loans.use: Replenish stock of fabrics

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeun R. is 41 years old and is a villager in Sam Raong village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Vany Pha, are farmers who own a small piece of land on which they cultivate rice to support their family living. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

In order to improve their living conditions, they want to start a new business but they do not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Sokhoeun R. decided to ask for a loan to buy a van to transport workers.

This couple has three children, one of whom helps the parents to farm while the others are studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a van to start a new business

loans.name: Selbe

texts.en:
Selbe T. is involved in buying and selling fabrics, a very common business among Senegalese women. Senegal and neighboring Mali, Mauritania and Gambia produce beautiful traditional fabrics, which are often in high demand, especially before important holidays. Ms. T. was introduced to the trade by one of her older sisters. As she is single and does not have children of her own, her income helps support her large extended family.
With her loan of 300,000 XOF she will purchase a large stock of fabrics. With the future revenues from her business, she hopes to open her own proper shop in the main market.
Ms. T. lives in the Ndayene neighborhood of Diourbel, a town of some 100,000 inhabitants, which shares its name with the larger Diourbel region. The region has around two million inhabitants, and inclues Senegal's second largest city, Touba. Before colonization, the region was known as the Bawol kingdom, and inhabitants are still often called Bawol-Bawol.

loans.use: To purchase a large stock of fabrics

loans.name: Chanthorng

texts.en: Mr. Chanthorng P. is 27 years old and a villager from Roluos village in Takeo province. He is the father of one child who is too young to study or work. Chanthorng P. is a farmer who owns one hectare of land to cultivate rice to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Mom Oreng (pictured right), is a laborer in a garment factory. However hard the family works, they do not earn sufficient income. Therefore, in order to improve their living conditions, they want to start a new business but do not have sufficient funds. So, Mr. Chanthorng P. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks for breeding.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for breeding

loans.name: Abdulmumin

texts.ru: Салимов Абдулмумин проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 58 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена работает поваром в столовой. Дети помогают обслуживать клиентов. Сам Абдулмумин 4 года как открыл свою столовую. Из- за увеличения количества клиентов он хочет расширить свой бизнес. Кредит берет для закупа посуды и мебели.
texts.en:
Abdulmumin S. lives in the Vahdat district. He is 58 years old, married and has 4 children. His wife works as a cook at a cafeteria. The children help service the customers. Abdulmumin opened his cafeteria 4 years ago. Due to the increased quantity of customers, he wants to expand his business. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of dishware and furniture.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of dishware and furniture

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Mr. Yan S. (pictured here) and his wife, Mrs. My Mon, live in a small village off National Road Two, about 18 kilometers south of Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1983 and have two sons and two daughters. Their eldest daughter works in a garment factory while the other three attend school.
Yan has been driving a remoque motor taxi (a motorbike with a trailer attached at the back) for more than 17 years. He carries people and goods from his village to Phnom Penh and back. His wife is a garment factory worker.
Yan has had a previous Kiva loan via Kiva partner, MAXIMA, to finish building his house. He is now requesting another loan of $1,200 USD to build a concrete room under his wooden house as, at present, he has an open-air space that is difficult to protect from the elements. He will also use a part of the loan to dig a well for family use.

loans.use: To build a concrete room under his wooden house and dig a well

loans.name: Tukundane Bakyara Group, Ibanda

texts.en: M. Brian is the leader of his lending group in Ibanda. He is a friendly and hardworking man who, for the last six years, has had a business dealing in art and design from Ibanda Main Street. Brian is married with one child and he also takes care of one dependant. He is happy that, because of the quality products that he makes, his business helps him to take good care of his family. Brian hopes to expand his business further and is requesting a loan to buy more inputs for boosting his business.

loans.use: To buy paints, clothes and boards for his business

loans.name: Vivisan

texts.en:
Vivisan is 38 years old, married, and has three children. The family live in Lagos State, Nigeria. Vivisan sells natural herbs to make a living. The herbs are use for the preparation of native medicine. Most people in her locality prefer using natural herbs for medication. Vivisan has been in this business for two years now. With the income from the business, she assists her husband, a commercial driver, to care and provide food for the children.
Vivisan hopes to increase her sales due to high demand for herbs by her customers. She is requesting a loan of 90,000 NGN to purchase more natural herbs to sell. She sends her thanks to Kiva and all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more natural herbs to sell

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao N. is 37 years old and lives in Roluos village in Takeo province. She is the mother of three children who all attend the local public school. Mao N. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sovana Tom (pictured right), is a duck seller. The family has a problem because their motorbike is too old to drive and they do not have enough money to buy a replacement. Therefore, Mrs. Mao N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new motorbike for selling ducks door to door.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for selling ducks door to door

loans.name: Penda

texts.fr: Madame Penda D.  mariée et mère de 5 enfants  est membre U-IMCEC Diourbel  depuis 2 mois. Elle vend des produits céréaliers tel que le niébé (haricots), arachide, fleurs de bissap,...etc depuis 10 ans dans son quartier  Ndayane à Diourbel. C’est de par sa grand-mère qu’elle embrassa ce métier. Cependant, elle a préféré vendre devant chez elle pour mieux attirer ses clients et, dit-elle, même la nuit les clients viennent acheter  des produits chez elle. Pour mieux faire face à la demande, elle sollicite un crédit de 50 000 FCFA  destinée à s’approvisionner en produits cerealiers auprès de ses fournisseurs.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of 5 children, Madam Penda D. is a member of U-IMCEC Diourbel for 2 months. She's been selling grain products such as niébé ( beans) peanuts, bissap flowers,... for 10 years in her neighborhood in Ndayane in Diourbel. It is through her grand mother that she embraced this trade. Meanwhile, she prefered to sell infront of her house to better attract her customers and according to her, customers come even in the night to buy products from her home. In order to better meet their requests, she is requesting a loan of 50 000FCFA for supplies of grain products from her suppliers.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grain products

loans.name: Ramatoulaye

texts.fr:
Madame Ramatoulaye G. sollicite un crédit de 150 000 FCFA pour un fond  de roulement de son commerce. En effet,  Madame G. s’est impliquée  dans le commerce pour mieux prévoir les charges familiales. Elle vend des produits céréaliers comme le mil, maïs, arachide…..etc. 
Madame Ramatoulaye G. est mariée mère de famille. Elle a 6 enfants dont les âges varient entre 12 mois et 11 ans. Elle compte actuellement  sur son commerce pour  compléter  les charges quotidiennes de la maison. C’est ainsi qu’elle remercie d’avance U-IMCEC et ses partenaires tout en espérant avoir un financement dans les plus brefs délais.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ramatoulaye G. is requesting a loan of 150,000 FCFA to use as working capital for her business. Mrs. G. became involved in trade in order to better provide for the needs of her family. She sells cereal products such as millet, corn, groundnut, etc. Mrs. Ramatoulaye G. is married and a mother. She has six children ranging in age from 12 months to 11 years. She currently relies on her business to fulfill her daily responsibilities at home. This is why she would like to thank U-IMCEC and its partners in advance, in hopes of receiving funds as soon as possible.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Or

texts.en: Mrs. Or C. is 60 years old and a villager from Roluos village in Takeo province. She is a mother of three children, all of whom are employed in a garment factory. Or C. is a farmer who owns 2.5 hectares of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chan Me, is shown on the right of the picture. The family has a problem because their field is ready to plow, but they do not have enough oxen to do the job. Therefore, Mrs. Or C. decided to ask for a loan to buy an ox to plow the field.

loans.use: To buy a ox for plowing the field

loans.name: Seynabou

texts.fr: Madame Ndiaye née Seynabou Guèye  est commerçante de pagnes et de draps, une activité qu’elle a embrassée depuis 2008 après la retraite de son mari.  Elle vend dans sa maison et fait aussi le marchand ambulant. Elle est à sa deuxième demande de crédit  et sollicite 150 000 FCFA pour acheter des tissus et accessoires nécessaires à la confection des pagnes et draps. Mère de 4 enfants, Madame Guèye âgée de 48 ans veut grâce à son  commerce, subvenir à tous ses besoins, sortir de la précarité  et devenir une très grande commerçante dans les plus brefs délais.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ndiaye, born Seynabou Guèye has been selling pagnes (robes) and sheets since 2008 after her husband retired. She sells from her home and also as an itinerant merchant. This is the second time she is requesting a loan - this time for 150,000 FCFA - to buy fabric and the accessories necessary for the confection of pagnes and sheets. 48 years old and mother of four children, Mrs. Guèye would like to see her business answer all her financial needs, help her rise above subsistence level and become a great merchant in a short period of time.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric and accessories

loans.name: Hamro

texts.ru: Баротов Хамро проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 67 лет. Женат, имеет 8 детей. Хамро более 20 лет занимается растениеводством. Он проводит севооборот и готовит землю для посева. В этом ему помогают жена и дети. Кредит берет для закупа семян.
texts.en:
Hamro B. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 67 years old, married and has 8 children. Hamro has been involved in agriculture for over 20 years. He is currently conducting seed processing and preparing the ground for planting. His wife and children help him with this business. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Tusitukire Wamu Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Jamila is 52 years old and the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a hardworking, married woman with four children aged between 7 and 30. She also takes care of some orphans.
Jamila is a farmer in Buikwe. She says that her business is doing well due to her good customer care and the loans that enable her to sell good quality produce. Although her business is doing well, she is faced with a scarcity of water for her plantations. Jamila has a dream of becoming a wholesaler of produce as well as educating all of her children to the highest levels of education. She is requesting a loan to help pay for her children’s education as well as buy more produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more produce and pay her children's school fees

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a 54-year-old, hardworking farmer who rear birds and fish to sell. She has been in this farming business for 17 years. She harvests and sells her farm products to customers at retail prices. Restaurant owners patronize her a lot for fresh fish as they use it to prepare a special delicacy – pepper soup – for their customers. Victoria also sells eggs at home and at the nearby local market. The old birds are usually sold off at the end of the farming season and new birds are purchased for the next farming season.
Victoria manages the farm business with her children in Lagos State, Nigeria. She hopes to expand her business and improve her family's standard of living. She is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more birds and fish to rear and sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more birds and fish to sell

loans.name: Sokunth

texts.en: Mrs. Sokunth S. is 43 years old and a villager from Prey Veaeng village. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sovanaret Heng (pictured right), is a policeman who earns a small salary. In order to improve the family's living conditions, Mrs. Sokunth S. decided to ask for a loan to buy six piglets for breeding. With the rest of the loan, she would like to buy pig food. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are employed in a hotel, while the other attends the local public school.

loans.use: To buy six piglets for breeding and pig food

loans.name: Arzibaeva Burmabu's Group

texts.ru:
Бурмабу, ей 46 лет, замужем. Вместе с супругом воспитывают 3 детей. Супруг работает в местном лесном хозяйстве. Старший работает в Бишкеке в Кока Кола Компани. Она занимается сельским хозяйством, в бизнесе активно участвуют все члены семьи. Данный кредит будет использован для аренды земельного надела, а также на закуп семян риса и минеральных удобрений. 

Адашкан, 46 лет, она вдова. У нее двоей детей, сын - 18 и дочь 14 лет. Сын занимается реализацией напитков, а дочь школьница. У Адашкан есть маленькое домашнее хозяйство, где она занимается разведением и откормом МРС, на кредит она планирует закупить 4 овец. 

Упол, ей 46 лет. Она замужем уже больше 25 лет, является матерью 2 детей. Сын учится в торговом колледже, а дочь в этом году заканчивает школу. У клиента имеется земельный надел, где она выращивает сельхоз продукцию, в основном рис, кроме этого выращивает МРС. Кредит будет использован для закупа 5 овец. 

Арзибек самый молодой участник этой группы. Ему 22 года, однако он играет не последнюю роль в группе. Он очень амбициозный и умный парень. Вместе с отцом занимается перепродажей скота на местном рынке. Кроме это его отец занимается пассажирскими перевозками на собственном автотранспорте. На кредит Арзибек планирует купить 2 овец и 4 козла для увеличения товарооборота.   


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Burmabu is 46 years, married. Together with her husband, she is raising 3 children. Her husband works at a local forest service. The oldest son works at the Coca Cola Company in Bishkek. Burmabu is involved in agriculture, and all family members actively participate in this business. The current loan will be used for leasing a plot of land and purchase of rice seeds and mineral fertilizers. Adashkan is 46 years old and a widow. She has two children: son is 18, and daughter is 14 years old. Her son is involved in selling beverages, and the daughter is a student. Adashkan has a small household, where she is involved in breeding and feeding small livestock. She plans to buy 4 sheep with this loan. Upol is 46 years old. She has been married for over 25 years and is a mother of 2 children. Her son is studying at a trade college, and the daughter will graduate from school this year. Upol has a plot of land, where she grows agricultural products, mainly rice. She also raises small livestock. This loan will be used for the purchase of 5 sheep. Arzibek is the youngest member of this group. He is 22 years old; however, his role in the group is not insignificant. He is a very ambitious and smart young man. Together with his father, he is involved in reselling livestock at the local market. Besides this, his father also provides passenger transportation using his own vehicle. Arzibek plans to purchase 2 sheep and 4 goats with this loan in order to increase turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Lease of land, purchase of seeds and fertilizers, and purchase of livestock

loans.name: Abdunazar

texts.ru: Пулатов Абдуназар проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка а дети учатся. Сам Абдуназар более 7 лет занимается животноводством. Он откармливает и продает скот. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Abdunazar P. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 36 years old, married and has 4 children. His wife is a homemaker, and the children are in school. Abdunazar has been involved in animal husbandry for over 7 years. He raises and sells livestock. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Sa Rorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sa Rorn K. is 42 years old and she lives in Samna Khmau village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1 hectare (2.5 acres) of land on which she cultivates rice to support her family living. Her husband, Mr. Chem Gneang, is a construction laborer.

This family has a problem because it is the time to do farming but they do not have money to support it. Thus, Mrs. Sa Rorn K. decided to ask for a loan to buy corn seed, fertilizer, pesticide, and to hire laborers for plowing the field.

Sa Rorn K. is the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, another is a construction laborer, another is attending the public school, while the other is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy corn seed, fertilizer and pesticide and to hire laborers to plow the field

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kabale Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Aisha is 32 years old and is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a hardworking married lady with five children aged 15 to 3 years, all in school. She also takes care of other orphans.

Aisha has been a farmer and a market vendor in Kiyindi for four years and her biggest challenge is the seasonality of her business and hence limited customers in such periods. She is able to make 70,000/= as weekly profits and she is grateful to her loans that enable her get quality produce for sale.

Aisha has a dream of becoming a shopkeeper of her own as well as educating her children to higher levels. She needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more produce to sell

loans.name: Chanda

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanda S. is 30 years old and she lives in Trapeang Kak village in Takeo province. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

Mrs. Chanda S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sona Nouch, is a duck breeder who owns a lot of ducklings but does not have money to buy duck food. So, in order to improve their family living conditions, Mrs. Chanda S. decided to apply for a loan to buy one tonne of rice for breeding ducks.

Mrs. Chanda S. is the mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school while the others are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy duck food for her husband's duck business

loans.name: H.

texts.en:
P. is a 60-year-old widow living with her six children. She owns a small piece of land where she grows spices and has her own cinnamon garden. She is growing the cinnamon with the help of her children.

P. wants to add more plants in her cinnamon garden in order to increase its capacity. She wants to expand her small business, and help her children too.

loans.use: To buy more cinnamon plants

loans.name: Da

texts.en: Mrs. Da H., who is a villager in Thnuoh village in Takeo province, is 37 years old. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare parcel of land to grow crops for supporting her family, and her husband, Mr. Ngous Sek, is a construction laborer, and on the side he is a fisherman also. In the rice field, this family has a problem because it was time to plow, but they did not have enough oxen to plow. Thus, in order to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Da H. decided to ask for a loan to buy an ox for plowing the field. She is a mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in local public school, while the other is employed in the garment factory. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy an ox for plowing the field

loans.name: Adaku

texts.en:
Adaku is 28 years old. She is married to Mr. I. who runs his own business and they live in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells articles like flashlights, poly bags, pens, calculators and more. She manages the business with the support of her husband. Adaku's dream is to have a big business that will enable her to save and reinvest money into the business. She left school due to financial constraints and her prayer is to support her husband in giving their children quality educations.

She hopes to expand and improve her business in the future. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more articles to sell. She says thank you to the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more articles like flashlights, poly bags, pens and calculators to sell

loans.name: N.e.g.

texts.en:
G. is a 30-year-old married woman living with her husband and their three kids. Her husband works in a sawmill.

G. conducts her small tailoring business from her home. She wants to improve her business so she can ensure higher education for her children in the future. Additionally, she wants to be self-sustainable, and hopes to create employment for others in the future.

loans.use: To buy cloth and other materials for designing dresses

loans.name: Hing

texts.en: Mrs. Hing M. is 54 years old, and she lives in Rung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare parcel of land to grow crops for supporting her family, and on the side she is a Khmer cake maker, who can sell some cakes in the local village door to door. She is a widow with three children, two of whom are employed in the garment factory, while the other is a driver who can get a small salary. In the crop field, this family has a problem because it was time to do farming, but they did not have the money for it. Thus, Mrs. Hing M. decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides, and with the rest of the loan she would like to hire laborers to plow the field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthy S. is 28 years old and lives in Damnak Reachea Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land for cultivating rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chanarak Sen, is a mechanic. However hard this family tries to work in their careers, they do not earn enough income. Thus, in order to improve the family's living conditions, Mrs. Chanthy S. decided to ask for a loan to start a new business buying groceries to re-sell in the local village. She is the mother of two children who are both too young to study or work. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy groceries to re-sell in the local village

loans.name: E.m.

texts.en:
K. is a 56-year-old married woman living with her husband and their four children in Telijjawila, part of the Matara district. Her husband is a day laborer, working full time.

It is very difficult for them to support their six-member family with only a day-laborer's income, so K. has a sewing machine and provides tailoring services to clients from her home.

K. wants to increase her business to help maintain her family properly and ensure that her children receive at least a minimum level of education.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and other accessories for dressmaking

loans.name: Lul

texts.en:
Lul H. is 34 years old. She is married to H. S. and they have four school-going children. For the last eight years, she has been selling clothes in Ndunyu Njeru, on the outskirts of Naivasha Town.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend, and this will be her second loan. She paid the first loan well and on time. She plans to use the cash as startup capital to set up another new clothes shop, still in Ndunyu Njeru market where demand is high.

In the future, she hopes to set up a big clothes shop in the town, catering to all types of people.

loans.use: Open another clothes shop

loans.name: Leap

texts.en:
Mrs. Leap O. is a villager in Prey Chheu Teal village in Takeo province and she is 38 years old. She is a widow with three children, one of whom is employed in a shoe factory while the others are attending the local public school.

Mrs. Leap O. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to support her family living. Moreover, she also owns a general store.

However hard this family tries to work with their careers, they are not able to earn enough income. Thus, in order to improve the family’s living conditions, Mrs. Leap O. decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to re-sell to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Zepyur

texts.en:
Zepyur H. lives in Sevan. For about nineteen years she worked as a commodity researcher. Since 1993 she has been engaged in clothes selling in a rented place.

Zepyur is married and has two daughters who have their own families and live separately from their parents. Zepyur’s husband is jobless and Zepyur takes care of her family with her business profit.

Zepyur needs a 770,000 AMD loan to organize a shoe-selling business and to buy spring clothes to sell.

loans.use: To organize a shoe sales business and to buy spring clothes to sell

loans.name: P. M.

texts.en:
G. is a married woman living with her husband and three children. Her husband is a mechanic.

G. has a small lunch packet supply business and her husband also helps her to supply the meals to customers. She wants to increase her supply of lunch packets with this loan in order to expand her business.

G. hopes to take care of her family better and create some employment through her business.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her lunch packet business

loans.name: God's Chosen Ones Group

texts.en: Jackson G. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God’s Chosen Ones. He is 35 years old, single, and is a high school graduate. He has two children who are 5 and 7 years old and who are in 1st and 3rd grade. In addition to his children, Jackson also supports his sibling. In the photo, Jackson is the one holding the sign. For six years, Jackson has had a slippers business at the Waterside Market, which is the largest market in Monrovia. He says that he provides high quality service in a friendly manner, which attracts customers. Jackson plans to use his 14,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 56,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more slippers. His goals are to grow his business, to help his children go to school, and to empower other family members as well. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more slippers to sell

loans.name: Groupe Sohkna Touré

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sokhna Touré est un groupement qui en est à sa deuxième demande de crédit  afin d’accroitre leurs chiffres d’affaires et faire face aux besoins familiaux. Ce groupement féminin qui porte le nom de la présidente  est composé de 8 membres tous habitantes de Diourbel.
 Elles s’activent toutes les 8 soit  dans le commerce, la teinture soit dans  la couture. Quant à la présidente Madame Sokhna Touré, elle vend des céréales locales, des légumes et détergents. Ainsi avec sa part du crédit, elle compte se réapprovisionner auprès de ses fournisseurs dans les plus brefs délais.  Elles sollicitent un crédit de 500 000  qu’elles vont se partager à part égale. 
Les autres membres du groupe sont Madame Fatou B., Madame Fary D., Madame Fatou N., Madame Ndeye Guèye, Madame Aïssatou S., Madame Oumou S. et Madame Faly T. toutes commerçants.
texts.en:
The Sokhna Touré Group is requesting a second loan to increase their turnover and meet their family needs. This group of women carries the name of its president and is made up of eight members, all from Diourbel. All eight are active in retail, dying or sewing. As for the president Mrs. Sokhna Touré, she sells locally grown grain, vegetables and detergent. With her portion of the loan, she intends to restock from her suppliers as quickly as possible. The group is requesting a loan of 500,000 that they will split equally among themselves. The other group members are: Mrs. Fatou B., Mrs. Fary D., Mrs. Fatou N., Mrs. Ndeye Guèye, Mrs. Aïssatou S., Mrs. Oumou S. and Mrs. Faly T., all running a business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen their businesses

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 32 years old. She owns a shop where she sells rechargeable phone cards. She has been in this business for two years now. She also has a photocopying machine which she uses as part of her business activities to generate additional income. Joy hopes to expand her business in the future. She is hoping for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell.

Joy is married; her husband is doing well in his own business and they live in Lagos State, Nigeria. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell.

loans.name: Respect The Law Group

texts.en: Gbessay M. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Respect the Law. He is 44 years old and is married with five children aged 1 to 13 years with educational levels of kindergarten through 3rd grade. In the photo, Gbessay is the one holding the sign. Satta N. is inset at lower right. Gbessay and his family live and work in Snapper Hill, Bassa town, a community that is filled with people that migrated from Grand Bassa County to settle in Monrovia to seek greener pastures. It is close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia. Gbessay could not continue his education through junior high school due to poverty. Gbessay's business is the sale of charcoal. He buys charcoal from rural Liberia and sells it to residents of his community. He has been running this business for five years and hopes to become a warehouse owner in the near future. He started by selling coal water (a fuel which consists of fine coal particles suspended in water) with a small amount of capital, but now goes out of town to buy his goods. He sells dry and strong charcoal in order to encourage his customers to continue buying from him. Gbessay needs this loan to purchase additional charcoal for resale to improve his business. He dreams of giving his family good medical attention. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Afolabi

texts.en:
Afolabi is 40 years old; she is married with four children who are all doing well in school. She and her husband hope to give their children a better education. Her husband does motor repairs and works very hard to provide for the family. Afolabi sells household items like plates, cups, pots, spoons, plastic buckets, and more. With the income from the business she assists her husband in providing for some basic family needs like food, clothing, school fees etc.

She hopes to expand her business in the future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more items to sell. Afolabi thanks all lenders for their support

loans.use: To purchase more household items such as plates, cups, pots, spoons, and plastic buckets to sell.

loans.name: Sargis

texts.en:
Sargis V. is 51 years old and lives with his wife and a son in Tsakhkunk village, Sevan area.

Sargis is machine-operator and he worked as a mechanization expert for about sixteen years. Now V.’s family is engaged in farming: they have cows, sheep and chickens on their farm and use the profit from their farming activities for their family needs.

Sargis asks for a 600,000 AMD loan to buy a cow and fodder for his farm animals.

loans.use: To buy a cow and fodder for his farm animals

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es:
La sra. Gladys V. propietaria de Coral Electronica, madre de 4 hijos y separada, el negocio posee mas de 20 años de antigüedad pero hace poco mas de 5 años que es de su propiedad pues anteriormente la cliente prestaba servicios como secretaria de la Firma hasta que falleció la dueña en aquel entonces y ella adquirió el negocio que le fue vendido por el viudo de la anterior dueña, la misma nos comento que siempre estuvo en el mismo lugar sobre las calles Parapiti y Blas Garay en pleno centro de la Ciudad De Asunción por lo que ya cuenta con su clientela.
Cabe menciona que la Sra. Gladys lleva adelante su comercio con la ayuda de 2 de sus hijos que también son técnicos en electrónica.
Asimismo cabe mencionar que le fue de mucha ayuda el crédito otorgado por la Fundación Paraguaya en la adquisición de repuestos de ciertos aparatos eléctricos como por ejemplo nebulizadores ultrazónicos por ser muy costosos y otros aparatos.
texts.en:
Sra. Gladys V. is the owner of Coral Electronics. She is separated and the mother of four children. Her business has been in existence for more than 20 years, but she took over the company more than five years ago after the death of the previous owner. Gladys was the firm’s secretary at the time and the owner’s widow decided to sell the business to her.

The business remains at its original location between Parapiti and Blas Garay Streets in the heart of the city of Asunción and still retains its customer base. It should be noted that Gladys manages her business with the help of two of her children, who are also electronics technicians.

Also worth mentioning is the loan provided by Fundación Paraguaya that was of great help in helping her acquire electronic spare parts for certain devices, such as ultrasonic nebulizers that can be very expensive, and other appliances.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase parts needed to repair various electronic devices

loans.name: Precious Women Group

texts.en:
Oldlady N. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Precious Women. She is 38 years old and is married with three children aged 2 to 8 years, with educational levels of 1st through 4th grade. She also cares for two siblings.

Oldlady and her family live and work in the Marshall, Elwa, community in Monrovia, Liberia. She was never able to continue her education through 1st grade due to lack of financial support from her parents. In the photo, she is the one holding the sign.

Oldlady’s business is the sales of raw fufu (cassava flour) and charcoal. She buys her goods wholesale from rural Liberia and sells to residents of Marshall in Elwa. She has been running this business for more than ten years and hopes to own a big shop in the near future. Oldlady started by selling with a little fund that was given to her by her husband but has now raised more funds for her family through her business.

Oldlady has a good management system and does not credit her customers. She also has a good manner of approach to her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. She needs this loan to purchase more fufu and charcoal to sell in order to improve her business.

Oldlady dreams of building a house for herself and her family.


About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more fufu and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Loveth

texts.en:
Loveth sells foodstuffs (yams) at retail prices. She has been in the business for some years and she is doing well. She manages the business with her children to make a living in Lagos State, Nigeria. She works hard to make sure there is food on her table.

Loveth hopes to expand her business in future. She hopes for the loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more yams to sell.

Loveth is 35 years old and is married with six children, her youngest being 5 years old. She hopes to support her husband in sponsoring the children to a higher level of education and that they be called, for example, mama doctor or lawyer in future. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr:
Âgé de 40 ans, Monsieur Abdoulaye Traoré N. est marié et père de six  enfants. Il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants au quartier Babemba de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Traoré après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au commerce d’achat et de vente d’oignons (grosses et petites graines)  qu’il exerce  depuis maintenant plus de huit ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ trois ans. Ainsi il sollicite ce quatrième prêt (après avoir correctement remboursé les trois précédents) pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter 10 tonnes (260 sacs) d’oignons de graines différentes.
 Il achète  ses marchandises à Niono et à N’Togonasso (respectivement dans les régions de Ségou et Sikasso) qui sont ramenées à Sikasso ville pour être vendues en détail ou en gros et au comptant les jours de foire à une clientèle composée essentiellement de forains.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 270 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdoulaye Traoré II is 40 years old, married and father of six children. He lives with his wife and their children in the Babemba neighborhood of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After several unsuccessful activities, Mr. Traoré started eight years ago a business of buying and selling onions (large and small varieties). He is quite in demand because of the quality of his products. Three years ago, to satisfy the increasing number of customers, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. He is now requesting a fourth loan (having fully reimbursed the three preceding ones), to increase his stock supply by acquiring 10 tons (260 bags) of different varieties of onions. He buys his supplies in Niono and N’Togonasso (respectively in the Ségou and Sikasso regions) and transports them to the town of Sikasso. There they are sold against cash - wholesale or retail - on market days, and for the most part to market vendors. He hopes using this loan will bring him to earn 270,000 FCFA per month, which will be used mainly to increase his stock supply, contribute to family expenses, pay off the loan and invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy onions (large and small varieties)

loans.name: God Knows Us Group

texts.en: Mary B. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Knows Us. In the photo, Mary is the one holding the sign. She is 45 years old and is a single mother with six children, all of them high school graduates and some of them now married. Mary and her family live and work in the Gbengber community in Elwa in Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. She was never able to go to school herself due to lack of financial support from her parents. Mary’s business is the sale of foodstuffs such as oil, pepper, garden eggs (eggplant), etc. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail to residents of her community. She has been running this business for more than twenty years and hopes to become a big businesswoman in the near future. Mary started selling with money that was given to her by her late husband but she is sometimes faced with rainy season problems because, when it rains, business can really be bad. Mary talks to her customers in a friendly manner in order to encourage them to continue to buy from her. She dreams of buying land to build a house for her family. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more oil, pepper and garden eggs to sell

loans.name: Erkinoy Abduhalilova's Group

texts.en: A. Erkinoy is a native of Aravan - she was born there. She is 50 years old and is married with three children: her son is in Russia at present; her first daughter is married and lives with her husband; while her youngest daughter just finished school and helps in the business. Her husband is a pensioner from the police force. Erkinoy works in a rural authorities office as a leading specialist in social security. Additional to this income, they have a family business fattening cattle. This loan will be used to buy a calf. Erkinoy is saving money to build a good sheep-yard. Banihan, 53, is the mother of two grown sons and also has two charming grandchildren. She started her own business after her divorce ten years ago. Since then she has achieved excellent results. At the present time she has five bulls, one cow in calf and one calf. Also she has land where she cultivate crops: rice, cotton and potatoes. This loan will be used to buy seeds for the spring sowing. Adinahon is 47 years old. She is involved in a livestock business and in farming, usually growing cotton. Her husband and son help her in this. Also they have a couple of cattle. This loan will be used to buy cotton seed and fertilizer because at the present time they are cheaper than in early spring. Parhatjon is the only male in this group. He is 46 years old and married with two children: a son and a daughter. He is involved in cattle raising and, at the same time, he is the personal driver of the local rural governor. Parhatjon started his livestock business in 2000 with just one cow. Now he is fattening eight bulls. With your support he will be able to buy 1 tonne of animal fodder (oil cake). ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a calf

loans.name: Adiara

texts.fr:
Madame  Adiara Berthé a  54 ans et réside avec son époux et leurs six enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’est initiée aux activités de teinture et de vente d’habits qu’elle a appris auprès d’une camarade il y a plus de vingt ans. Après  avoir teint les bazins, elle coud quelques pièces en chemises masculines qu’elle revend. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement des voyageurs et des routiers) pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Vu le positionnement de sa boutique située à la gare routière de Sikasso, son activité marche bien et la clientèle est très satisfaite.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante et exigeante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis  de six ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 10ème prêt individuel, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursé.                                                                                             Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 15 pièces de bazins blancs, 15 boîtes de teintures de couleurs différentes, 15 paquets de soude caustique et quelques pièces de pagnes wax. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako ensuite elle les revend dans sa boutique située au cœur de la gare routière de Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 350 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adiara Berthé is 54 years old and lives with her husband and six children in Sanoubougou I, a working-class neighborhood in the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Given her social environment, she did not have the opportunity to further her education, and more than 20 years ago learned from a friend the rudiments of dying and selling clothes. After dying the Bazin cloth, she assembles several pieces to make men’s shirts for sale. She is much in demand by her customers (for the most part travelers and truck drivers) for the quality of her products. Because her shop is well located at the Sikasso bus station, her business is flourishing and her customers are very satisfied. She decided six years ago to join the Doro Yiriwaso MFI, to better satisfy an increasing number of customers with high expectations. After participating in a few group loans with a neighborhood women’s loan group, she is now up to ten individual loans, all of which have been fully reimbursed. With this loan she intends to buy: 15 pieces of white bazin fabric, 15 containers of dye in various colors, 15 packages of caustic soda, and a few pieces of ‘pagne wax’ cloth. She gets her supplies from Bamako, then resells them in her shop located in the center of the Sikasso bus station. She expects this loan will help bring her monthly earnings up to 350,000 FCFA, which she will use to increase her stock of supplies, contribute to family expenses, repay her loan and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bazin fabric, pagnes cloth, caustic soda and dyes

loans.name: Alassane

texts.fr:
Né le 22 janvier 1970 à Abidjan (république de Côte d’Ivoire) Monsieur Alassane C.est marié et père de deux garçons. Il réside avec sa  famille à Wayerma Zone, un des quartiers populaires de la  ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant appris la réparation  de radio depuis tout petit auprès de son père, Monsieur Coulibaly  parallèlement à cette activité, mène  une activité d’achat et de vente des appareils électroniques (TV,Mine Chaîne, DVD, etc) dans son atelier  sis au quartier Fama en face du boulevard ’’Voxon’’ il y a environ quinze ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses activités. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a quelque mois avec laquelle il est à son premier prêt individuel. 
Monsieur C.vend ses appareils (TV, Mines Chaînes, DVD, batteries, etc) dans son atelier de réparation à ses clients composés généralement de ceux qui sollicitent ses services de réparations.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter, 3 DVD, 2 TV écran 29, 2 Mines Chaînes, des CD, etc. Ses appareils proviennent de la république du Ghana.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born January 22, 1970 in Abidjan (Republic of Côte d’Ivoire), Mr. Alassane C.is married and the father of two boys. He lives with his family in Wayerma Zone, a working-class neighborhood in the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). At an early age, Mr. C.learned to repair radio sets from his father. Fifteen years ago he set up a workshop in the Fama neighborhood facing Voxon Boulevard, where he also buys and sells electronic equipment (TVs, mini-hifi systems, DVD players, batteries, etc.). Mr. C.sells the equipment in his repair workshop to customers who for the most part are in need of repairs. He is in high demand due to the quality of his services. To satisfy an increasing number of customers, he decided a few months ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, where he is requesting his first loan. He intends to buy: three DVD players, two 29” screen TVs, two mini-hifi systems, CDs, etc. His supplies come from the Republic of Ghana. This loan should increase his monthly income to 100,000 FCFA, which he will use to increase his stock of equipment, contribute to family expenses, repay his loan and invest the remainder in his business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy electronic equipment

loans.name: Aoua

texts.fr:
Née le 10 Juillet 1968 à Sikasso, Aoua Traoré est une femme mariée mère de 2 enfants qui vit dans une famille polygame avec son époux, sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans la famille paternelle de son époux à Kaboïla II au centre ville de Sikasso.(troisième région du Mali)
Secrétaire Dactylo de formation, elle est issue d’une famille de teinturière  ce qui témoigne de son attachement  et dextérité pour cette activité qui lui rapporte gros.  
Madame Aoua Traoré est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso il y a  trois  ans. Elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel, le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Elle sollicite ce prêt pour acheter, 15 pièces de bazin blanc, 20 sachets de soude caustique et 20 boîtes de teintures de couleurs différentes.
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako en matières premières (bazins blancs, soude caustique et teinture) pour les mettre en couleur et ensuite les revendre soit au comptant ou à crédit. Elle a pour  clientèle potentielle, les revendeuses de bazins teintés, les couturiers, les femmes de son quartier, etc. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 200 000 FCFA qui lui permettra de couvrir l'essentielle de ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer à celles de son foyer en aidant son époux, payer les intérêts de son prêt et renforcer son activité de teinture.
texts.en:
Born on July 10, 1968, in Sikasso, Aoua Traoré is a married woman and the mother of two children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, his co-spouse, and their children, in her husband's paternal family in Kaboïla II in the center of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). Trained as a secretary and typist, she comes from a family of dyers, which shows her bond and dexterity to this profession, which earns her quite a lot. Mrs. Aoua Traoré has been associated with Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, for three years. She's seeking her second individual loan, and the previous one was repaid without problems. She's seeking this loan to buy 15 lengths of white Bazin fabric, 20 sachets of sodium hydroxide, and 20 boxes of dyes of different colors. She gets her supplies (white Bazins, sodium hydroxide and dyes) in Bamako, and then dye them before selling them, for cash or on credit. Her potential customers are women who resell dyed Bazins, tailors, women in her neighborhood, etc. She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 200'000 (ca US$ 400) which will enable her to pay for most of her personal expenses, help her husband with the family expenses, repay the loan, and strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Bazin fabrics, dyes, and sodium hydroxide

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 26 Décembre 1963 à N’Kourala préfecture de Sikasso, Mariam Koné est veuve et mère de quatre  enfants. Elle réside avec ses  propres enfants et d’autres, adoptifs, à Médine-Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Mariam Koné après avoir avoir perdu son époux il y a dix sept  ans, s’est initiée  commerce  avec la vente des condiments alimentaires et des légumes. Elle vend au nouveau de marché de Sikasso dont elle dispose d’un magasin et d’une table où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a quelque mois. 
Elle sollicite ce premier prêt pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter, 5 sacs d’oignons de graines différentes, 5 sacs d’aloko, 5 sacs de pomme de terre et divers autres condiments et légumes.
Elle achète ses marchandises sur place auprès des paysans venant des villages environnants pour les ramener dans les marchés hebdomadaires de Yorosso et Kouri vers la frontière Mali-Burkina Faso pour être vendues en détail ou en gros au comptant les jours de foire à une clientèle composée essentiellement de forains.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on December 26, 1963, in N'Kourala, Sikasso Prefecture, Mariam Koné is a widow and the mother of four children. She lives with her own children, as well as other, adopted ones, in Médine-Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After losing her husband 17 years ago, she got started in business by selling food condiments and vegetables. She sells her goods at the new Sikasso market, where she has a shop and a table. She's very much in demand due to the quality of her products. A few months ago, she decided to join Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, in order to meet an ever-increasing customer demand. She's seeking this first loan to bolster her working capital, in order to buy 5 sacks of onions of different types, 5 sacks of aloko (a snack made from fried bananas), 5 sacks of potatoes, and various other food condiments. She gets her supplies locally from farmers coming from the neighboring villages to bring them to the weekly fairs in Yorosso and Kouri, near the Mali-Burkina Faso border. She sells for cash, retail and wholesale, during fair days to a clientele comprising mostly fair vendors. With this loan, she foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 100'000 (ca US$ 200), to be used mostly to bolster her working capital, help with the family expenses, and repay the loan. The remainder will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 sacks of onions, 5 sacks of aloko (a snack made from fried bananas), 5 sacks of potatoes, and various other food condiments

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Salimata Traoré est une femme mariée de 42 ans, mère de 4 enfants qui vit avec son époux  dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Fama, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Salimata Traoré après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à la fabrication des savons traditionnels (savons noirs) depuis plus de cinq ans, qu’elle a appris auprès d’une voisine. Elle mène son activité dans son domicile de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya  3 année avec laquelle est à son 4ème prêt individuel, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursé. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 15 fûts des déchets d’huile de coton, 8 sacs de soude caustique et 5 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe. 
Après fabrication des savons à base de déchets d’huile de coton et de soude caustique, elle les revend en détail à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes de sa localité.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Salimata Traoré, age 42, is a married woman and the mother of 4 children. She lives with her husband in a large traditional family in Fama, in downtown Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After running several unsuccessful businesses, she started selling traditional soaps (black soap) five years ago, a business she learned from one of her neighbors. She runs this business at home in Sikasso, where she's very much in demand due to the quality of her products. To meet an ever-increasing customer demand, she decided to join Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, three years ago. She's seeking her fourth individual loan, and all previous loans were repaid without problems. She intends to use this loan to buy 15 drums of cotton oil waste, 8 sacks of sodium hydroxide, and 5 wagonloads of firewood. After making soaps from cotton oil waste and sodium hydroxide, she retails them to a clientele usually composed of women of her town. With this loan, she foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 200'000 (ca US$ 400), to be used mostly to bolster her working capital, help with the family expenses, and repay the loan. The remainder will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 15 drums of cotton oil waste, 8 sacks of sodium hydroxide, and 5 wagonloads of firewood

loans.name: Maïmounata

texts.fr:
Madame Maïmounata Diallo  est une femme mariée de 29 ans et mère de 2 enfants qui vit avec son époux et leurs enfants  à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée à l’activité  de teinture auprès  d’une  des  grandes teinturière  de la place depuis plus de deux  ans. Elle réjouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes surtout lors des cérémonies (Mariage, baptême, fêtes, etc.). 
Ses ressources financières propres ne peuvent pas lui permettre de satisfaire sa clientèle.  C’est ainsi, qu’elle sollicite ce prêt pour acheter, 8 pièces de bazins blancs, 10 boites de teintures de couleurs différentes et 10 sachets de soude caustique.    
 Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les gros commerçants en matières premières (bazins blancs, soude caustique et teintures) pour les mettre en couleur et ensuite les revendre soit au comptant ou à crédit, elle a pour clients, les revendeuses des bazins teintés, les couturiers et les femmes de son quartier.
Madame Maïmounata D.est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis depuis plus de sept  ans. Après  4 prêts solidaires  avec une association des femmes de son quartier et est maintenant à son 7ème prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursé.
Avec ce prêt, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 250 000 FCFA qu’elle compte utiliser pour de ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer aux dépenses familiales en aidant son époux, payer les intérêts de son prêt et renforcer son activité de teinture.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maïmounata Diallo, age 29, is married and the mother of two children. She lives with her husband and their children in Hamdallaye, a working-class neighborhood in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After running several unsuccessful businesses, she got started two years ago in the tinting business, with one of the famous local dyer. She enjoys a strong reputation in this business, and gets many orders, especially for celebrations (wedding, baptism, etc.). Her own financial resources do no enable her to meet customer demand. This is why she's seeking this loan, in order to buy 8 pieces of white Bazin fabric, 10 boxes of dyes of different colors, and 10 sachets of sodium hydroxide. She gets her supplies locally, from wholesalers (white Bazins, sodium hydroxide, and dyes), tint the fabrics, and resell them, for cash or on credit. Her customers are resellers of tinted Bazins, tailors, and women of her neighborhood. Mrs. Maïmounata D.has been associated with Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, for more than seven years. After four group loans with a group of women of her neighborhood, she's now seeking her seventh individual loan. All previous loans were repaid without problems. With this loan, she intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 250'000 (ca US$ 500), to be used to pay her personal expenses, help her husband with the family expenses, repay the loan, and bolster her tinting business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 8 pieces of white Bazin fabric, 10 boxes of dyes of different colors, and 10 sachets of sodium hydroxide

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Né le 09 Août 1978 à N’Golo-Diassa situé à environ 6 km de la ville de Sikasso, Monsieur Moussa Berthé  est marié et père de deux enfants. Il réside avec sa femme et leurs enfants dans une  grande famille traditionnelle élargie  dans son village natal, relevant de la préfecture de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Berthé est un mécanicien de profession depuis plus de huit ans. 
Pour rendre service à ses nombreux clients d’acquérir des pièces auto sur place sans déplacement, il mène en plus de la mécanique cette activité d’achat-vente des pièces détachées d'occasion. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux  ans avec laquelle il est à son troisième prêt individuel.Tous les prêts précédent ont été remboursé.
 Il compte acheter, des bielles, arbre à came, pistons, jantes, etc. Les marchandises (pièces) sont achetées sur places issues des démontages des véhicules pour être vendues  dans son magasin  sis au sein de son garage.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Moussa Berthé was born on August 9, 1978 in N’Golo-Diassa, located approximately 6 km from the city of Sikasso. He's married and the father of two children. He lives with his wife and their children in a large extended traditional family in his birth village, part of the Sikasso prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. Bethé has been a trained mechanic for eight years. As a service to his numerous customers who wants to buy spare parts locally to avoid traveling, he also runs a business buying and selling used spare parts. He's very much in demand due to the quality of his products. To meet an ever-increasing customer demand, he decided two years ago to join Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso. He's seeking his third individual loan, and all previous loans were repaid without problems. He intends to buy connecting rods, camshafts, pistons, rims, etc. The parts are bought locally and comes from dismantled vehicles, and are sold in his shop inside his garage. With this loan, he foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 100'000 (ca US$ 200), to be used mostly to bolster his working capital, help with the family expenses, and repay the loan. The remainder will be invested in his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used spare parts (connecting rods, camshafts, pistons, rims, etc)

loans.name: Ma. Lanie

texts.en: Ma. Lanie C. is a 48-year old married woman who lives in Hacienda Vista Alegre, Barangay Eustaquio Lopez, Silay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by food vending, by operating a general store and a motor shop and by manufacturing hollow blocks. In the photo, Ma. Lanie poses with the sand heap that is the main raw material for making hollow blocks. Ma. Lanie’s husband, Reynaldo, manages the hollow-blocks business which is their biggest source of income. They have four children who are between 20 and 27 years old, some of whom work and help support the family. Ma. Lanie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in December 2003 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her various businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000 from her business activities. Ma. Lanie is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,500 was used to fund operations of her businesses and it had a positive impact on both the businesses and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 20,000 for her 15th loan which she again intends to use as additional working capital for her businesses. Ma. Lanie is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Sakha
