texts.fr: Madame Sakha F. célibataire et mère d’un enfant âgé de onze ans est une femme de ménage dans une école supérieure depuis presque 2 ans.  Elle est très connue  également dans la vente de produits cosmétiques et habits pour bébés. Cette femme née en 1972  s’approvisionne jusqu’en Mauritanie  et les place à sa clientèle composée même de commerçants et d’amis. Elle souhaite  un financement de 200 000 FCFA pour acheter ses produits, assurer le transport et les frais de douane. Elle ne s’active, dit- elle, que pour satisfaire les besoins de son enfant.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sakha F. was born in 1972. She's single and the mother of one 11-year-old child. She's been a cleaner in a superior school for almost two years. She's also very well known for selling cosmetics and baby clothing. She gets her supplies in Mauritania, and sells them to her customers, comprising merchants and friends. She's seeking a loan to buy new products, and to pay for transportation and customs taxes. She says she works to support her child.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and baby clothing

loans.name: God Give Group

texts.en: Rose G. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Give. In the photo, Rose is the one holding the sign. She is 45 years old and is married with five children aged 3 to 22 years, with educational levels of kindergarten through university student. She also cares for two siblings and a parent. Rose and her family live in Rock town, Elwa community, and she works in the Elwa market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia's capital. Rose herself was never able to continue her education through college due to lack of financial support from her parents. Rose’s business is the sale of crushed rock for construction. She breaks rocks into pieces and sells it to residents of Elwa that are into construction in Monrovia. She has been running this business for two years and hopes to own a wholesale and retail outlet in the near future. Rose started her business with three hundred Liberian dollars in capital. She faces a problem with the eight to nine-month rainy season because, when it rains, people don’t come out to buy which is not good for business. Rose sells clean and shining rocks in order to encourage her customers to continue buying from her. She needs this loan to purchase additional rock for resale to improve her business. Rose dreams of giving her children the best education and establishing businesses for them. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional rock to sell

loans.name: Fatoumata Yéhia

texts.fr:
Madame  Fatoumata Yéhia Y.est âgée de 46 ans et mère d’une fille. Elle réside avec son époux à Bougoula-Ville, Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales,  elle  s’est  très vite initiée  à une activité génératrice de revenu notamment l’achat et la  vente d’articles divers tels  le  lait en poudre, les moquettes, couvre-lits, cache-murs et autres il y a maintenant dix  ans. Elle passe les commandes de ses marchandises à Gao (7ème région administrative du Mali) en provenance d’Algérie dans le Maghreb.  Elle les revend de façon ambulante dans les différentes structures professionnelles de la ville. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Elle vend ses marchandises au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis quelque mois. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour acheter,  4 cartons de laits en poudre, 6 moquettes de différentes dimensions, 5 couvre-lits, 2 paires de cache-murs, 4 cartons de Couscous arabe et divers autres articles maghrébins.                                                                                           Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Yéhia Y.is 46 years old and mother of one daughter. She lives with her husband in Bougoula-Ville, Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali) Without the opportunity to further her education due to social factors, she engaged very soon in revenue-generating activities, and ten years ago began buying and selling various products such as powdered milk, carpets, bedcovers and wall coverings. Her merchandise comes from the Algerian Maghreb, but she places her orders in Gao (seventh administrative region of Mali). She resells her merchandise as an itinerant vendor in various professional areas in town. She is in high demand due to the quality of her products. Her customers pay either cash or on credit in monthly installments. To satisfy the ever increasing number of customers, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI a few months ago. She will use this loan to purchase: four cartons of powdered milk, six carpets in different dimensions, five bedcovers, two pairs of wall coverings, four cartons of Arabian couscous, and a variety of other products from the Maghreb. This loan should increase her monthly income to 150,000 FCFA, which she will use mainly to increase her stock of supplies, contribute to family expenses, repay her loan and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products

loans.name: Busaana Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
O. John is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a hardworking and friendly married man with seven children of his own. He also takes care of two orphans. John says that three of his children have left school and are working with him in his fishing business while the rest are still in school.

Although he was a security guard before the transformation, John has been in the fishing business since 2003 and employs three people with whom he shares the day’s catch. From his business, he is able to make 100,000/= in a good week but at times this reduces to 50,000/= during off seasons.

John would like to expand and start poultry farming, especially broilers, in addition to his business and he has already set up the shelter for them. This loan will help him with buying the day-old chicks.

loans.use: To buy day-old chicks for his new business

loans.name: Ma. Gina

texts.en:
Ma. Gina R. is a married woman who supports her family by raising pigs and running a general store. She lives in Inalad, Siaton, Negros Oriental with her husband, Jovencio, who is 38 years old, and their five children who are 6 to 18 years old and all currently going to school.

Ma. Gina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and her pig fattening business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 8,900.

Ma. Gina is now borrowing Php 25,000 to buy feeds for  her pigs and also continue buying inventory for her general store. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 17,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom.

Ma. Gina aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.


 About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy feeds for her pigs and additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Fousseni

texts.fr:
Né le 1er Mai 1969 à Sikasso Monsieur Fousseni Traoré est marié et père des 4 enfants. Il réside dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Kaboïla II, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Traoré après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initié à cette activité de sonorisation il y a environ 5 ans. Il dispose à la fois une discothèque et d’une salle de jeu devant le domicile, il est beaucoup  sollicité  surtout lors des cérémonies de mariage, baptême, anniversaires, etc. Cette salle de jeu est équipée en  téléviseurs avec lesquels les jeunes viennent se divertir en  jouant le Play-Station.
 Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a quelque mois avec laquelle il sollicite son premier prêt individuel pour pour une diversification de ses services en achetant, un ordinateur (pour graver les sons et images) et des DVD. Il compte acheter ses marchandises au Ghana.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born the first of May, 1969 in Sikasso, Mr. Fousseni Traoré is married and father to four children. He lives in a large, traditional family which expands to Kaboila II, the center of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. Traoré, after having tried many trades without success, began work in the audiovisual trade about five years ago. He manages a discotheque and a game hall in front of his home. He is often solicited for wedding ceremonies, baptisms, birthdays, etc. The game hall is equipped with televisions with which youth come to have fun and play Play Station. With the goal of better satisfying his ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso a few months ago. He is asking for his first individual loan to diversify his services by buying a computer (to burn sounds and images) and DVDs. He plans on buying this merchandise in Ghana. He sees making a monthly profit of 200,000 FCFA with this loan which he will use to increase his commercial funds, contribute to his family's needs, pay the interest on the loan, and invest the rest in his work.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Electronic Equipment

loans.name: Jappo Liggey Group

texts.fr:
Jappo Liggey  ou en français  « MAIN DANS LA MAIN POUR TRAVAILLER »  est un groupement féminin qui regroupe en son sein 5 femmes commerçantes toutes habitantes dans le quartier Angle Serigne Fallou de Thiès une ville située à 70 Kms de Dakar. Il a été formé, il y’a tout juste un an,  et est  dirigé par la plus âgée Madame Mame Dior M. née en 1949. Pour le renforcement de leurs activités les membres de ce groupe souhaitaient un financement de 500 000 FCFA qu’elles vont se partager à part égale.
 Madame Mame Dior M. mère de 8 femmes est  très physique et dynamique. Elle  fait le commerce depuis plus de 40 ans et en a même acheté une maison avec les bénéfices générés par le   travail. Cependant, avec sa part de ce  prêt, 100 000 FCFA, Madame Mame Dior M. compte acheter divers produits pour son commerce. Elle veut acheter du melon, le melon récolté avec le projet de la GOANA (Grande Offensive  Agricole pour la Nourriture et l’Abondance) un projet mis en œuvre par le président  Abdoulaye Wade pour développer l’agriculture et faire face à la sécurité alimentaire. Cet investissement de Madame M. lui permettra de renforcer son travail et d’accroitre ses bénéfices. 
Quant aux autres  membres du groupe, elles sont : Madame Rama N. restauratrice dans son quartier depuis 18 ans, Madame Aminata D. vendeuse de cacahuètes et fruits au niveau de l’école élémentaire du quartier depuis 20 ans, Madame Ramatoulaye M. restauratrice devant le portail d’une école supérieure de la ville et Madame  Mame Néné D. vendeuse de sandwich, jus , habits et chaussures au niveau de son quartier.
texts.en:
"Jappo Liggey" (translated: Working Hand in Hand) is a women's group consisting of five women merchants who all live in the Angle Serigne Fallou neighborhood of Thiès, a town situated 70 km from Dakar. This group was formed just one year ago and is led by the oldest member, Mrs. Mame Dior M., who was born in 1949. In order to bolster their businesses, the members of this group would like a loan of 500,000 F CFA of which they are going to receive equal shares.

Mrs. Mame Dior M., the mother of 8 young women, is an energetic lady. She has been working as a merchant for more than 40 years and has even managed to buy a house out of the profits from her business. However, with her share of this loan, 100,000 F CFA, she plans to buy various items for her business. She wants to buy melons harvested by the project "Great Agricultural Campaign for Food and Abundance" which was instituted by President Abdoulaye Wade to expand agriculture and address the issue of food security. This investment of Mrs. M. will allow her to bolster her little business and increase her profit.

As for the other members of the group, they are: Mrs. Rama N. who has been serving cooked food in her neighborhood for 18 years, Mrs. Aminata D. who has been selling roasted peanuts and fruit at the elementary school for 20 years, Mrs. Ramatoulaye M., who sells cooked food outside a high school in town, and Mrs. Mame Néné D. who sells sandwiches, juice, clothing, and shoes in her neighborhood.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: re-stock their businesses

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadia S. a 38 ans et vit avec son époux et ses 4 enfants  à Kaboila I Natien, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Kadia S., après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès,  s’est initiée à cette activité de restauration  depuis maintenant  dix ans. Elle mène son activité devant le domicile conjugal en face de l’ancienne Direction Régionale des Affaires Sociales tous les jours. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses plats alimentaires. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis cinq ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter,  3 sacs de pomme de terre, 40kg de viande de bœuf, 60kg de poissons frais, 5 litres d’huile alimentaire, 2 paquets de maggie, 2 bidons de vinaigre, 60 sachets d’Attièkè, 2 sacs de charbon de bois, 20 miches de pain et  des bananes plantains. 
Elle achète ses marchandises sur place et effectue ses ventes au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  généralement de jeunes (célibataires)  et des travailleurs du marché. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs Kadia S. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Kaboila I Natien, in the center of Sikasso (third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). After several unsuccessful attempts, Mrs.S. started a restaurant business some ten years ago. She operates her business daily, in front of her home and just across from the former Regional Direction of Social Affairs building. She is in high demand from her customers because of the high quality of her food preparations. To satisfy the needs of an increasing number of clients, she decided five years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance association. After several group loans with an association of neighborhood women, she is now on her second individual loan. All these loans were duly repaid. With this loan she plans to buy: three bags of potatoes, 40 kilos of beef, 60 kilos of fresh fish, five liters of cooking oil, two packages of Maggi cubes, two jugs of vinegar, 60 packets of Attiéké (cassava root), two bags of charcoal, 20 loaves of bread and plantain bananas. She buys her merchandise locally and resells it for cash or credit to a customer base made up of young single people and market workers. She expects to earn a monthly profit of 250,000 FCFA which will be mainly used to increase her stock of supplies, contribute to family expenses, pay off her loan, and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients for her restaurant business

loans.name: Blessed Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Prossy is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 31 years old and married with four children aged 13 to 4 years. She also takes care of orphans.

Prossy is a business lady involved in hawking (selling door-to-door) tablecloths from Mbikko. She has been in her business for five years and her business, being competitive, gives her a chance to have quality materials for sale.

Prossy used to deal in secondhand clothes and she does not regret the change she made. She is grateful for her loans that have helped to hold her head high in business and she would like to grow her business further as well as educating her children to the higher levels.

Prossy needs a loan to be able to buy more tablecloths for resale.

loans.use: To buy more tablecloths to sell

loans.name: Johnson Street Business Center Group

texts.en:
Augustine S. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Johnson Street Business Center. In the photo, Augustine is the one holding the sign. He is 56 years old, married, and is a high school graduate. He has seven children who range in age from 13 to 35.

For eight years, Augustine has had a building-materials business on Johnson Street. He says that he provides high quality service in a friendly manner, which attracts customers.

Augustine plans to use his 14,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 56,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more building materials such as planks, nails and cement. His goal is to grow his business, to help his children go to school, and to build a house.


About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more construction supplies to sell

loans.name: And Liggey Group

texts.fr: Le groupement  And Liggey ( ou « ensemble pour travailler » ) sollicite un prêt de 500 000 FCFA pour le développement du commerce de ses membres.  C’est un groupe composé de 5 femmes micro entrepreneuses. Il est dirigé par Madame Ndeye Astou D. âgée de 44 ans. Cette femme mère de 4 enfants est commerçante de divers produits comme orange, mangue, melon, poissons séchés et fumés au marché. Influencée  par sa maman qui vendait des légumes au marché, elle embrassa l'activité en 2000 pour mieux aider sa famille et son mari dans la gestion de la maison. Sa part du crédit  lui permettra de s’approvisionner auprès des grands fournisseurs. Les autres membres s’activent aussi dans le commerce. Il s’agit de Madame Ndiapaly Ndour N. vendeuse de melon et poissons séchés, Madame Malada D. vendeuse de pain de singe, arachide et huile de palme, Madame Coumba S. vendeuse de fruits et d’arachide chez elle et de Madame Mame Diarra N. vendeuse de thé, produits de lessive et oignons.
texts.en:
The group "And Liggey" (or "Together to Work") is asking for a loan of 500,000 FCFA for the commercial development of its members. This is a group made up of five micro-entrepreneurial women. It is lead by Mrs. Ndeye Astou D., aged 44 years old. She is the mother of four children. She trades various products like oranges, mangoes, melons, and dried and smoked fish at the market. Influenced by her mother who sold vegetables at the market, she entered the trade in 2000 to better help her family and husband with the family's needs and management. Her part of the loan would allow her to compete with larger suppliers. The other members of the group are also active in trade. Mrs. Ndiapaly Ndour N. sells melons and dried fish, Mrs. Malada D. sells Baobab fruit, peanuts, and palm oil, Mrs. Coumba S. sells fruit and peanuts at her home, and Mrs. Mame Diarra N. sells tea, cleaning products, and onions.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stockage of various products

loans.name: Rock Of Ages Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
W. Julius is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a sincere and hardworking man, married with seven children aged 14 to 3 years. He also takes care of two orphans from his late sister.

Julius has been a fishmonger from Busaana Landing Site for seven years and he is able to make 70,000/= as profits from the fish that he sells. He buys fresh fish and smokes them for his customers who buy from his workplace.

Before he started getting loans, Julius was a fisherman but left that to buy the fish and smoke them himself since his wife is also involved in some other businesses of her own. Julius needs a loan to be able to buy more fish that he will smoke for resale.

loans.use: To buy more fish to smoke and sell

loans.name: Esperanza Divina 2, 3 Group

texts.en:
Dorka is the coordinator of her group, Esperanza Divina (Divine Hope), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). Her group is located in Hato Mayor, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home there in a simple structure as a single mother with her child.

Dorka is excited to be taking out her seventh loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing by purchasing more merchandise to sell such as jeans, blouses and underwear. She also plans to buy a glass display case.

Dorka will use the profits to invest in her family by purchasing school supplies for her children, by refurbishing her home, and by purchasing high-quality fertilizer so that she can grow vegetables in her backyard. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy blue jeans, blouses and underwear to sell

loans.name: Women Of Hope Group

texts.en: Garmai N. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Women of Hope. In the photo, Garmai is the one holding the sign. She is 45 years old and is married with three children aged 14 to 24 years, with educational levels of 6th grade through college student. Garmai and her family live in the New Matadi Community, and she works in the New Matadi Peace Market about fifteen minutes drive from downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She was never able to go to school herself due to lack of financial support from parents. Garmai’s business is the sale of charcoal. She buys her charcoal from rural Liberia and sells it in the Matadi Peace Market. She has been running this business for three years and hopes to own a bigger business in the near future. She started selling with 3,000 Liberian dollars as working capital but now operates with nearly 20,000 Liberian dollars. Garmai sells dry charcoal and has a good relationship with her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. She needs this loan to purchase additional charcoal for resale. Garmai dreams of seeing her children get educated and of having a good home in the future. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: God's Grace Group

texts.en:
William F. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God’s Grace.  He is 32 years old, single, a college graduate, and has two children who are 4 years old and 5 months old.

For eight years, William has had a phone card business on the corner of Gurley and Broad Streets in downtown Monrovia. He says that he takes good care of his business, which attracts customers.  

William plans to use his 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 34,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more phone cards.  His goal is to have a good life.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, William is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase phone cards.

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El comité “La  Esperanza”tiene  mas de 2 años de formación y trabaja con la Fundación Paraguaya , la mayoría de sus integrantes ya  venia realizando actividades productivas, pero incluyeron entre sus integrantes a  3 señoras que     ahora emprenderán actividades. Incluyen entre las actividades realizadas la venta de frutas y verduras , venta de comestibles artesanales como empanadas de carne ,empanadas de pollo ,empanadas de jamón y queso ,venta de mercaderías varias como :fideo ,azucar , harina ,aceite, jabón, entre otros artículos ,venta de ropas , venta de remedios etc.
Anhelan un futuro mejor para sus hijos, es por eso que se esfuerzan el doble para facilitarles los materiales  para  su desarrollo y formación. 
Entre la integrantes del comité siempre resulta interesante escuchar las experiencias de vida de la Sra. Maria M. quien se dedica a la venta de remedios yuyos, esta actividad es realizada por muchas personas en Paraguay ya que se consume mucho los remedios naturales.
 La Sra. Maria nos comenta que se provee de sus remedios yuyos de varias formas muchas veces del Mercado de Abasto o en otras ocaciones con la ayuda de su hijos recorre algunos lugares   donde se puede encontrar estas plantas y ellos mismos lo recogen y piensa que esto resulta más por que la ganancia es mayor. 
Ademas de la Historia de Sra. Maria la demás integrantes realizan su propia actividad, se lista abajo:
       1
Susana F.
Venta de Ropas
2
Marlene B. 
Copetin
3
Patricia G.
Kiosco
4
Gisela V.
Vendedora Ambulante
5

Venta de verduras

6

texts.en:
The Committee “La Esperanza” (The Hope) was formed more than two years ago and has been working with Fundación Paraguaya. Most of the group are involved in productive activities, but also includes among its members three ladies who are just starting their businesses. The types of activities represented include retail businesses selling fruits and vegetables; handicrafts; empanadas filled with beef, chicken, ham, or cheese; grocery items such as noodles, sugar, flour, oil and soap; clothing; medicines; and other products. The members yearn to provide a better future for their children. As a result, they double their efforts in acquiring the materials needed for the development and growth of their businesses.

It is always interesting to hear about the life experiences of some of the committee members, such as Sra. Maria M.. Maria sells herbal remedies, an activity that is practiced by many in Paraguay because of the popular consumption of these elixirs. Her products are frequently offered in various forms at the suppliers’ market. On other occasions, with the help her of children, she travels to different places to find and gather herbs in order to increase her earnings.

In addition to Sra. Maria, the other group members and their businesses are listed below:

1. Susana F. – clothing sales 2. Marlene B. – liquor sales 3. Patricia G. – vending kiosk 4. Gisela V. – street vendor 5. Sindia L. – vegetable sales 6. Zulma I. – clothing sales 7. Teodora D. – clothing sales 8. Blanca V. – grocery store 9. Maria de Jesus C. – sewing supplies 10. Alicia F. – fruit sales 11. Faustina S. – cheese bread sales 12. Rogelia E. – empanada sales 13. Maria M. – herbal remedies 14. Marta B. – sewing supplies 15. Claudia B. – dressmaker

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Sulema

texts.es:
La señora Sulema L. ella es maestra de educación y además de ser maestra se dedica al comercio y tiene su negocio en su casa de habitación en Esteli.
El tipo  de negocio que tiene es venta de ropa, cosméticos, comida y útiles escolares, este negocio tiene aproximadamente de tenerlo 10 años el cual inicio con ahorro propio y con la ayuda de su esposo.
Sulema va destinar el crédito para la compra de útiles escolares y ropa ya que tiene cerca del negocio dos colegios y varias fabrica procesadora de tabaco el cual el personal que labora es cliente de ella ya que le brinda crédito a un pL. de una semana.
Ella espera que con la compra de compra de útiles escolares y la ropa aumente su inventario de mercadería y así obtener mayores ganancias.
Sulema es casada y tiene dos hijos a su cargo ambos en edad escolar y tiene dos empleada.
Este es el primer crédito con Ceprodel y expresa continuar trabajando con Ceprodel.
texts.en:
Sulema L. is a teacher but she's also a merchant and has a store in her home in Esteli. She sells clothing, cosmetics, food, and school supplies. She has had this business for 10 years; she started it with her own savings and with help from her husband. Sulema will use the funds to buy school supplies and clothing because she has two schools nearby and several tobacco processing plants, whose employees are customers because she extends one-week's credit to them. She hopes that by stocking school supplies and other merchandise her inventory will be greater and therefore so will her profits. Sulema is married and has two, school-age children under her care; she also has two employees. This is her first loan with Ceprodel and she hopes to continue to collaborate with Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise and school supplies.

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou S. est une dame ménagère elle habite a la sicap baobab ou elle exerce un commerce de jus de fruits et de glace elle est membre a la caisse de liberté 6 depuis 2007 a son troisième pret elle sollicite un montant de 200 000 F CFA pour renforcer ses activités
texts.en:
Fatou S. is a housewife living in Sicap Baobab, where she runs a business selling fruit juices and ice-cream. She has been a member of the Liberté 6 village bank since 2007. For her third loan, she is requesting 200,000 CFA Francs to boost her activities.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to boost her business

loans.name: Confianza Y Desarrollo 2 Group

texts.en:
Hector is the coordinator of his group, Confianza y Desarrollo (Confidence and Development), and his story is representative of his group and of Esperanza's Dominican and Haitian (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. His group is located in the areas surrounding San Pedro De Macoris, an agricultural area once booming with the sugar industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. He makes his home here in a simple structure as a single father with three kids.

Hector is excited to be taking out his sixth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid his previous loans and grown his business. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business selling dulce de coco, a sort of candy covered concoction of ground coconut and milk, which he sells from his motorcycle. He will invest by purchasing the necessary ingredients of milk, coconut and sugar, he also has his eye out for a suitable machine to grind the coconuts with. He will use the profits to invest in his family by purchasing school supplies for his children and in his home by purchasing a new roof. His long term goal is to see his children finish high school and go to the university to be professionals. He thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Milk, Sugar and Coconut

loans.name: Five Sisters Group

texts.en:
Martha D. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Five Sisters. She is 50 years old and is a widow.  She has 3 children aged 15-30 years old and their educational levels are 6th grade to high school graduate.  In addition to her children, she also cares for 2 siblings.

Martha and her family live in the New Matadi community, and she works in New Matadi Peace Market which is about 15 minutes from downtown Monrovia.  She was never able to go to school herself due to lack of financial support from her parents.

Martha’s business is the sale of dry fish. She buys fresh fish from fishermen, then dries the fish and sells it. She has been running this business for 32 years and hopes to own a bigger business in the near future.  Martha started selling with a small amount of money from her late husband.  She has been facing problems recently with the high prices of goods and too many vendors with the same business in the New Matadi Peace Market.

She talks to her customers in a friendly manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.  Martha needs this loan to purchase additional fish.  She dreams of giving her children the best support in every positive thing they are involved in.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Martha is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional dry fish.

loans.name: Mukama Ayambe Group, Mukono

texts.en: K. Julia, inset in the photo that accompanies this profiel at upper left, is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 48 years old and a widow taking care of her eight children of which two are in school. Julian is a business lady who has been buying and selling produce like matooke, cassava, sweet potatoes, greens and vegetables, for 10 years.  She grows some of the produce she sells herself. She is in need of a loan to help buy more produce for resale plus to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and produce for resale, and to pay for children's school fees.

loans.name: Respect Yourself Group

texts.en:
Sarah C. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Respect Yourself. She is 66 years old, widowed, and has two children who are 45 and 30 years old.

For over 20 years, Sarah has been selling cooked bowls of food at the Rally Town Market. Her children gave her money to start her business.  Sarah knows a lot about her business, which keeps customers coming back.  

Sarah plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 24,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy ingredients to cook with and bowls in which to serve food.  Her goal is to help her children and grand-children build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Sarah is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase cooking ingredients and bowls in which to serve cooked food.

loans.name: Lweza Intergrated Group, Kampala

texts.en:
N. Nulu is a hard working and devoted lady who has had a retail shop business in Lweza for six years. She is married with three children who are all in secondary school. From her shop sales, Nulu, highlighted at lower left in the photo that accompanies this profile, is able to make 125,000 Ugandan shillings as weekly profits, although she is faced with challenges like the late payments of debtors.

This is Nulu’s first time to seek for a loan from Kiva field partner Pearl Microfinance.  She hopes to expand her shop, and in future to turn it into a wholesale shop. She also hopes to have a reputable and educated family so that they all become self reliant. She needs this loan to help with increasing stock at her shop, and hopes it will result in increased profits.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Fatou Bounama

texts.fr: Cette dame Fatou M. habite au Sacré Cœur 3 non loin de la caisse de liberté 6 sociétaire elle s'active dans la vente des chaussures, pagnes, écharpe, encenses pour dame elle veut renforcer ces activités en sollicitant un crédit de 400 000 F CFA pour une durée de 12 mois
texts.en:
This lady, Fatou M., lives in Sacré Cœur 3, not far from the Liberté 6 village bank she is a member of. She runs a business selling shoes, pagnes (robes), scarves and incense to ladies. She wants to boost her activity; for this, she is requesting a loan of 400,000 CFA francs for a duration of 12 months.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolster her business

loans.name: Bujakukya Group, Kampala

texts.en:
Hadija Bint A. is the leader of her lending group in Kampala. She is a friendly and hardworking lady who is married with three children, as she takes care of two dependents. She has a retail business selling clothes from the Cooper Complex near the Kabalagala taxi stage in the center of Kampala. She has been in business for four years and this is her first loan. Her good communication skills have enabled her to win more customers. 

A. has a dream of opening up a bigger shop so that she becomes financially successful. She needs a loan to be able to buy more clothing stock for sustainability.

loans.use: Buying more stock of clothes for resale

loans.name: Ganyana Busabala Group, Kampala

texts.en: Ruth N. is 60 years old and is a very hard-working lady with a continuous drive to succeed. She is the mother of seven children, with several grandchildren to take care of. Ruth is from Busabala and has been a farmer for eight years, growing foodstuffs for sale as well as keeping animals and birds for milk and meat. She is quick to say that her past loans have enabled her to expand and excel in her business. She currently needs a loan to be able to buy fertilizers and more produce for resale since this season was not favorable for her.

loans.use: Buying fertilizers and more produce for resale.

loans.name: God's Grace Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God’s Grace. She is 45 years old and is married, with five children whose educational levels range from 4th grade to vocational student. Elizabeth and her family live in Gbenbger Town, and she works in the VOA Market in the ELWA community on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She was never able to go to school herself due to the lack of financial support from her parents.

Elizabeth’s business is the sale of fufu, a local Liberian food. She buys her goods from wholesalers in rural Liberia and sells retail at the market. She has been running this business for 13 years and hopes to own a bigger business in the near future. She sometimes faces problems because customers do not buy all of her fufu, which leads to it spoiling because it gets too soaked. Elizabeth needs this loan to grow her business, and she dreams of being able to support all of her children.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Elizabeth is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more fufu, porridge made from cassava flour, a local Liberian food.

loans.name: Andrea Estefania

texts.es:
Andrea P. de 20 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y solo tiene luz como servicio básico, su esposo es chofer de un taxi con el tiene 1 hijo de 4 años.

Ella comenzó desde muy pequeña ayudar a su mama en la tienda que ella tenía, cuando creció quiso tener su propio negocio y empezó vendiendo artículos de bazar.   

Ahora Andrea trabaja desde las 07h30 atendiendo la pequeña papelería que tiene vendiendo cuadernos, lápices, zapatos, etc. Uno de los inconvenientes que tiene es que su negocio no es muy visible para los clientes.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar zapatos, cuadernos, ropa para temporada playera todo para su negocio. En el futuro quiere ampliar su negocio y tener artículos para hogar.
texts.en:
Andrea P. is 20 years old and lives in the periurban district of Paraíso in Guayaquil. Her home is made of cement and receives electricity as its only basic service. Her husband is a taxi driver, and together, they have a child who is now four years old.

As a little girl, Andrea helped her mother in the store that she managed. When she got older, she wanted to have her own business and started selling merchandise at a bazaar.

Today Andrea begins work at 7:30am at her small stationery store where she sells notebooks, pencils, shoes, and other items. One of the drawbacks that she has to deal with is that her business is not very visible to her customers.

With this loan, Andrea will buy shoes, notebooks, and seasonal beach clothing for her business. In the future, she wants to expand her business and acquire products for the home.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seasonal clothing, notebooks, and shoes

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Antonio M. vive en vivienda propia, en la zona German Busch, de la ciudad de El Alto. Es casado y tiene dos hijos, 
El señor Antonio trabaja como portero en un edificio de la ciudad de La Paz y su esposa vende cosméticos en un puesto ambulante,  ingresos  con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de dos habitaciones en su vivienda, que no cuenta con el espacio suficiente para sus hijos.
Esta es la segunda vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Sr. Antonio M. lives in his own home in the German Busch District of the city of El Alto. He is married and has two children. Antonio works as a doorman at a building in the city of La Paz and his wife sells cosmetics as a street merchant. Both of their incomes help to support their family.

The loan he is requesting will be used to add two bedrooms to his home because there is not enough space for his children. This is the second time Antonio has requested a loan. The socioeconomic analysis indicates he has a favorable rating and is able to access another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build two bedrooms for his children

loans.name: Amalia

texts.es:
La señora Amalia vive en casa propia con su esposo e hijos en la zona de alto sopocachi de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como profesora en provincia.

El crédito que solicita es para pagar la educación de su hija que se encuentra en último curso en la Universidad y de esta manera ella pueda salir profesional.

Es cliente de Impro y tiene un historial de pagos muy bueno, por lo que puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Sra. Amalia lives in her own home with her husband and children in the district of Alto Sopocachi in the city of La Paz. She works as a teacher in the province.

The loan she is requesting will be used to pay her daughter’s education. She is in her final year of university and this will allow her to go on to become a professional.

Amalia is a client of IMPRO and has a very good payment history, so she is able to access a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for her daughter's room & board at college

loans.name: Erwin

texts.es:
El señor Erwin vive en casa de sus padres en casa propia en la zona vivienda obrera de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como ayudante en viajes a los yungas (localidad a tres horas al norte de La Paz).

El crédito que solicita es para pagar la operación de su madre quien tuvo un accidente y tiene fractura en el pie.

No es cliente de Impro pero por el carácter social puede acceder a un crédito.
texts.en:
Señor Erwin lives in his parents’ house in the Vivienda Obrera neighborhood of the city of La Paz. He works as an assistant on trips to the Yungas region, located three hours to the north of La Paz. The loan that he is applying for is to pay for an operation for his mother who had an accident and fractured her foot. He has not previously been a client of IMPRO but, due to his good character, he can be approved for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The cost of an operation for his mother, who fractured one of her feet.

loans.name: Escarlete

texts.es:
La señora Escarlete vive en casa de sus padres en la zona de Alto San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como empleada en un proyecto de la Alcaldía.

El crédito que solicita es para pagar su ultimo curso de arquitectura y poder graduarse de esta manera poder mejorar sus ingresos y su posición en el trabajo.

No es cliente de Impro pero por la actividad puede acceder a un crédito. Este será su primer crédito.
texts.en:
Mrs. Escarlete lives in her parents house in the Alto San Pedro zone of the city of La Paz. She works as an employee in a project of the mayor's office. The credit she requests is to pay for her final architecture course, enabling her to graduate and, in this manner, to improve her income and her position at work. She is not a client of IMPRO but due to her activity, she is eligible to gain access to a loan. This will be her first loan.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PAYING FOR HER FINAL ARCHITECTURE COURSE, ENABLING HER TO GRADUATE

loans.name: Dionisio

texts.es:
El señor Dionisio vive en casa propia con su esposa e hijos en la zona de Pasankeri de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como constructor.

El crédito que solicita es para instalar una pensión (es un pequeño restaurante donde sirve almuerzo y cena a clientes seguros que pagan por el total de un mes) para su esposa, ya que construyo su casa y habilito una tienda para que su esposa colabore con los ingresos de la familia.

Es cliente de Impro y tiene un historial de pagos muy bueno, por lo que puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Mr. Dionisio lives in his own house with his wife and children in the Pasankeri zone of the city of La Paz. He works as a builder. The loan he requests is for installing a 'pensión' (a small restaurant which serves breakfast and supper to subscribing customers who pay by the month), for his wife. He has already built his house and equipped it with a store, so that his wife can contribute to the family income. He is a client of IMPRO and has a very good history of making payments, and for that reason he can have access to a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: FOR INSTALLATION OF  A SMALL RESTAURANT FOR HIS WIFE

loans.name: Women Of Progress Group

texts.en:
Marion W. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Women of Progress. She is 41 years old, married, and has four children who are 1, 4, 7 and 10 years old. In addition to her children, Marion also takes care of her siblings.

For three years, Marion has been selling charcoal at the Rock Hill Diamond Creek Market. She purchases high quality charcoal, which keeps people returning.

Marion plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more charcoal. Her goal is to grow her business and to have all of her children attend school.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Marion is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal.

loans.name: Our God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Timothy K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Our God is Able. He is 32 years old, married, a university graduate, and has two children who are 3 and 4 years old.

For five years, Timothy has been selling bags of rice on 12th street in Monrovia. He says that he sells the rice at a good price, which attracts customers.

Timothy plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more bags of rice. His goal is to grow his business and to be in good health.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Timothy is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of rice.

loans.name: Justiniano

texts.es:
Justiniano se dedica a  ser Artesano en joyas para damas de pollera, además tiene una tienda de abarrotes, es su principal fuente de ingreso con que cubre la mantención de su familia, tienen 2 sobrinos que dependen de él y tienen 12 y 14 años de edad. Tiene su domicilio en la Zona de Yunguyo de la ciudad de El Alto.
 
El préstamo lo destinará a la compra de materia prima (Oro y Plata).
 
Es su segundo crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago le permite solicitar otro préstamo.
texts.en:
Justiniano sells handmade traditional jewelry; in addition he has a small grocery store. This is his primary source of income and with it he supports his family, including 2 nephews who are his dependents who are 12 and 14 years old. His home is in the Yunguyo area of the city of El Alto. He will use this loan to buy raw materials (gold and silver.) This is his 2nd loan with IMPRO, and his good credit history makes it possible for him to request another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy gold and silver for his jewelry-making business

loans.name: La Superacion Group

texts.en:
Eufrecia is the coordinator of her group La Superacion (The overcoming), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located on the Samana peninsula, a lush but rugged area with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and two children.

Eufrecia is excited to be taK. out her second loan from Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business in interior design. She plans to purchase cloth, decorations and thread along with an industrial sewing machine to create curtains and sofa covers. She will use the profits to invest in her home by finishing construction on it and in her family by purchasing a computer for her children to learn on. Her long term goal is to have a large business in a good location with many employees and a vehicle to make deliveries. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread, decorations and an industrial sewing machine

loans.name: Las Rosas Y Las Guindas Group

texts.es:
El Bancomunal Las Rosas y las Guindas, inicia su 6to ciclo con 17 socias, está ubicado en el distrito D. Lircay, departamento D. Huancavelica, L. actividad principal D. L. comunidad es el comercio.
Sus socias se dedican a L. venta D. verduras, abarrotes en los mercados y ferias D. L. comunidad.
Una D. sus socias es Teodora, que es casada y tiene 3 hijos, 2 varones y 1 mujer, empezó su negocio D. ventas D. verduras con un pequeño puesto en las ferias D. L. comunidad, ahora gracias a los prestamos tiene más capital para invertir y sus ventas han crecido, con el préstamo que va a recibir implementará su negocio con L. venta D. abarrotes, comprará al por mayor arroz, azúcar, aceite y productos D. primera necesidad que tienen mayor venta. El sueño D. Teodora es tener un almacén D. mercadería, para tener su negocio con productos variados y que nunca le falten.
texts.en:
The community bank Las Rosas y Las Guindas starts its 6th cycle with 17 members; it is located in the district of Lircay, department of Huancavelica; the group’s main activity is commerce. Its members sell vegetables and groceries in the markets and fairs of their community. One of the members is Teodora; she is married and has three children, 2 boys and 1 girl. She started her business of selling vegetables with a small stall in the community’s fairs; now, thanks to the loans, she has mO. capital to invest and her sales have grown. With the loan she will receive, she will add the sale of groceries to her business; she will buy wholesale rice, sugar, oil and basic necessity products that sell the most. Teodora’s dream is to have a grocery stO., a business with assorted products, always in stock.

Translated from Spanish by Carlos Morales, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic necessity products to sale

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es:
El Sr. C. tiene 60 años, esta casado con la Sra. Maria Fiore, tienen cuatro  hijos mayores de edad, todos trabajando.
El Sr. C. tiene una Herrería hace 22 años en ciudad de Capiatá, localidad muy cercana a centro de San Lorenzo  sobre la ruta principal Nº 2, su domicilio esta a tres cuadras de su negocio. Su Sra. tiene una pequeña librería en su domicilio hace 5 años.
Gracias al esfuerzo de ambos terminaron de construir su vivienda propia y  de solventar sus gastos familiares y también esta creciendo comercialmente.
Este crédito invertirá en la compra de mercaderías e insumos para su herrería.
texts.en:
Antonio is 60 years old. He is married to Maria and they have four adult children, all working. Antonio has had a blacksmith shop in the city of Capiata for the past 22 years. The city is located along Route 2, very close to the center of San Lorenzo. His home is three blocks from his shop. His wife has run a small bookstore from her home for the past five years. Thanks to their efforts, they’ve managed to build their own home, save some money and grow their businesses. This loan will be used to buy supplies and provide working capital for the blacksmith shop.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for blacksmith shop

loans.name: Edelberto

texts.es:
El señor Edelberto vive con sus hijos en la zona de Pasankeri de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja actualmente como panadero, pero con el anterior crédito que se le dio hizo construir un horno en su casa.

El crédito que solicita es para la compra de una máquina sobadora de masa y herramientas para instalar el horno que construyó anteriormente  y habilitar la panadería en su casa. Edelberto quiere comprar los insumos para la elaboración de pan y también las mesas, latas, etc.

Es cliente de Impro y tiene un historial de pagos muy bueno, por lo que puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Edelberto lives with his children in the Pasankeri area of the city of La Paz. He currently works as a baker. With the previous loan granted to him, he was able to construct an oven in his home. He is requesting the current loan in order to buy a kneading machine for bread dough, as well as the necessary implements to install the oven he previously constructed and to begin operating a bakery in his home. Edelberto also wants to buy ingredients to prepare bread, as well as tables, bread pans, etc. Edelberto is a client of Impro and has an excellent payment history, allowing him to qualify for a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a kneading machine and implements to install an oven

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buying a motorcycle

loans.name: Mallana Group

texts.en:
Anthony F., the leader of this group of five borrowers called Mallana, is 33 years old, married, a university graduate, and has two children who are one and three years old. For three years, Anthony has been selling metal products in Monrovia.  He says that he sells high quality products, which attract customers. Anthony plans to use his 10,400 Liberian dollar portion of this 52,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more metal products.  His goal is to grow his business and to send his children to school.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Anthony is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously-operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional metal products, such as locks and cages.

loans.name: Mi Fortaleza En Cristo Group

texts.en:
Laura is the coordinator of her group, Mi Fortaleza en Cristo (My Fortress In Christ), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the area surrounding Santiago known for its production of beef and tobacco, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband.

Laura is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having fully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her used clothing business by purchasing large packages of used clothing that come from organizations such as The Salvation Army. She will use the profits to save, as she looks forward to starting a family. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase large packages of used clothing

loans.name: Elba María

texts.es:
En el Barrio Costa Hermosa del municipio de Soledad, Atlántico, vive una mujer inspiradora de tenacidad y esfuerzo propio que en condición de jefe de hogar ha sacado a sus 3 hijos adelante ; ella es Elba María Bastos, gran emprendedora de negocios que desde que asumió la obligación de ser madre inició vendiendo refrescos embotellados y helados y con el producto de sus ganancias y su persistencia en el ahorro logró dotar su negocio de su primer enfriador y cajas de refrescos que vendía al detal y progresivamente al por mayor. Con este negocio logro educar a su primer hijo en estudios superiores; pero gradualmente la jornada laboral extendida a la que se sometió la llevó al cansancio extremo y decidió cambiar su actividad por la venta de comidas rápidas, actividad que realiza en los fines de semanas y para la que compró un carro de perros calientes. En la actualidad tiene un negocio vende carne asada, perros calientes, hamburguesas, que combina con diversos insumos, como parte de su potencial innovador y que se han convertido en las delicias del barrio Costa Hermosa, donde vive gente trabajadora que aprecia la calidad de sus productos, la higiene con la que trabaja porque saben que ella cuida de su salud. Ella simultáneamente vende mercancía cosmética, aprovechando la admirable capacidad mercadológica que la caracteriza. 

Elba María nunca ha dejado de ahorrar, trabaja con el crédito de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo hace un año, cuando fue recomendada por su hermana que también recibe beneficios de los servicios de esta organización. En la actualidad aspira a un crédito por valor de $2.000.000 para incrementar la venta de comidas rápidas en la época carnavalera e invertir mercancía cosmética sobre pedidos. Su sueño a corto plazo es comprar un local propio aspira a acceder al proyecto de viviendas en Villas e San Pablo y con su Asesora Aury Perez están en estos trámites y en especialmente intenta aplicar al subsidio estatal para ese fin. Asocia el éxito de su negocio con la disciplina, la persistencia y esto lo a demostrado , porque con él que ha logrado sostener su hogar y continuar con la educación de sus hijos y acceder a cursos de conducción, pagarle la carrera de procesos industriales y continuar preparándolos para que sean mayores la oportunidades a las que ellos puedan acceder.
texts.en:
In the neighborhood of Costa Hermosa, municipality of Soledad, Atlantico, lives an inspiring woman with tenacity and initiative, and being the head of household, she has managed to get her 3 children ahead in life. She is Elba María Bastos, a great entrepreneur that ever since she assumed the responsibility of being a mother, she started selling bottled drinks and ice cream. With her profits and persistence in saving, she managed to obtain her first refrigerator for the business, and crates of drinks that she would sell first at retail, and progressively at wholesale. With this business, she was able to provide a higher education for her first son, but the extended labor required led her to extreme exhaustion; she decided to change her business to selling fast food, an activity that she does on the weekends and for which she bought a hot dog cart. In her current business, she sells carne asada (grilled steaks), hot dogs, hamburgers, which she combines with other consumables as part of her innovative potential; her food has become a delight in the Costa Hermosa neighborhood, a community of hard working people that appreciate the quality of her products, and the cleanliness of her operation since they know health is a priority for her. She also sells cosmetics products, taking advantage of the admirable marketing skills that characterize her. Elba María has never stopped saving; for a year now, she works with loans from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo; she was recommended by her sister who also benefits from the services of this organization. She currently aspires to get a loan of $2,000,000 (Colombian Pesos) to increase the sales of fast food during carnival season, and to increase cosmetic merchandise sold to order. Her short-term dream is to buy her own establishment, and she also aspires to participate in the housing project Villas de San Pablo; she is going thru the process with help from her advisor Aury Perez and she is planning to apply for government assistance. She attributes the success of her business to discipline and persistence, demonstrated by her, since she has been able to provide for her home, take driving lessons, afford the education of her children, pay for an industrial engineering education, and continue to prepare her children so they can have more opportunities available to them.

Translated from Spanish by Carlos Morales, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy consumables to prepare and sell fast food; also buy cosmetic products sold to order.

loans.name: Angelica Maria

texts.es:
Angélica E. de 27 años, vive en una zona urbana en el Suburbio de Guayaquil, su casa es de caña pero si cuenta con todos los servicios básicos, es madre soltera tiene 2 hijos de 3 y 5 años que estudian en escuelas particulares.

Angélica empezó con un puesto pequeño de comida afuera de su casa vendiendo platos como arroz con menestra y pollo asado al pasar de los años tuvo muy buenos ingresos.

Ahora Angélica vende platos como pescados al vapor, arroz con pollo, parrilladas de carnes etc. Comienza a vender la comida desde las 18h00 hasta las 22h00 su promedio de clientes es de 30. Una de las complicaciones que tiene son las lluvias.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, carnes, legumbres para poder hacer más platos de comida. En el futuro quiere un restaurante con empleados.
texts.en:
Angélica is 27 years old and lives in the urban part of Suburbio de Guayaquil. She lives in a thatch house, but she has all of the basic services. She is a single mother and has two children, ages 3 and 5, who study in a private school. Angélica started with a small food stall outside her home, selling dishes such as rice with vegetables and grilled chicken. Over the years she has had a good income. Now Angélica also sells other dishes, such as steamed fish, chicken with rice, and grilled meats. She begins selling her food at 6:00 pm and continues until 10:00 pm. She serves an average of 30 customers. One of her complications is the rain. She would like to use the money from this loan to buy ice, meats, and beans in order to be able to make more food dishes. In the future she would like to open a restaurant with her own employees.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chicken, rice, meats and other ingredients

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of used clothing in bales for resale

loans.name: Sebastian

texts.es:
Sebastián H. R. tiene 53 años de edad y se dedica a la elaboración de bollos de maíz acompañado se su cónyuge quien aparece en la fotografía que lo apoya todo el proceso productivo y especialmente el de comercialización, una vez hacen la producción sale por las calles con su ponchera desde las 5:00 AM, pues debe estar temprano en la calle para que las familias desayunen con el delicioso producto que ellos elaboran; él además de tener su propio negocio también está empleado parte del tiempo en una clínica, por eso su cónyuge es su apoyo idóneo (aparece con Sebastián en la foto), con ella  tiene  3 hijos de 33, 31 y 8 años de edad. 

Sebastian nació en  San Basilio de Palenque, la tierra que vio nacer a  folcloristas, boxeadores mundiales, actores y otros personajes importantes y donde la champeta y la Tambora son parte de la cultura de esta población en el Caribe Colombiano. Ellos viven en el barrio la manga  lugar donde viven muchos afrodescendientes caracterizados por su carácter alegre, trabajador y muy solidario. 

Inició su negocio elaborando alegrías, producto de forma circular a base de millo, panela, coco y anís estrellado, pero por ser un negocio muy estacionario, decidieron dedicarse a la fabricación de bollos de mazorcas, cocadas y de enyucado (torta a base de yuca que muelen, agregan crema de leche, queso y hornean). Este es su segundo crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo por valor de $1.500.000 y utilizara una parte para comprar materias primas e insumos de sus productos, para vender en las fiestas que se avecinan y la otra parte y las utilidades  que se generen en esta época, para organizar un punto de producción y venta, porque en la actualidad el proceso productivo se encuentra dividido entre el patio y la cocina familiar. Ellos están satisfechos pues con su primer crédito lograron comprar un molino pues tenían que pagar por este proceso en otro barrio ahora lo hacen directamente y se ahorran el arriendo.
Como Sebastian y su esposa quieren sacar adelante su negocio, tienen como sueño principal, poner un punto de venta y para eso   cuentan con un lote de su propiedad que adecuaran para realizar su sueño. Mientras tanto Sebastian continua feliz, participando en grupos sociales con su comunidad afrodescendiente, ellos  se ayudan  mutuamente   y comparten,  su música,  sus  ideas y   costumbres tradicionales.
texts.en:
Sebastián is 53 years old. He makes corn fritters with his wife, who is also in the photograph, who helps him with the manufacture and especially the sales. Once he makes the fritters, he goes out, beginning at 5:00 AM. He must be out early so that families can enjoy their delicious product for breakfast. Besides having his own business, he also works part time in a clinic, so his wife provides him with important support. Together they have 3 children, ages 33, 31, and 8. Sebastián was born in San Basilio de Palenque, a land which has also witnessed the birth of folk dancers, world class boxers, actors and other important personalities. It is also a place where "Champeta" (a musical genre of independent and local origin from the African descendents) and Tambora (drumming) are part of the culture of the Columbian Caribbean. They live in the "la Manga" (the sleeve) neighborhood, an area where many African decedents live and are known for their cheerful and hard working characters. He started his business by making " alegrías," a small round treat made with millet, raw sugar, coconut, and crushed anis. They decided to start making corn fritters, coconut candies, and cassava cakes (made by grinding up yucca and adding cheese and cream and then bake). This loan of 1,500,000 COP ($750) will be their second loan through " la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo." They will use the money to buy ingredients and supplies, so they can sell their products in the upcoming festivals, and to consolidate their production area, which is currently split between their family kitchen and patio. They are happy because they were able to buy a mill with their first loan. They used to have to pay for grinding to be done in a different neighborhood, but now they are able to do this themselves and are able to save on the cost. Since Sebastián and his wife would like to move their business forward, they would someday like to establish a point of sale on a lot located on their property, which they will set up to achieve their dream. In the mean time, Sebastián continues to be happy participating in social groups within his African decedent community. They help one-another and share their music, ideas, customs and traditions.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo R., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients and supplies

loans.name: Marisol Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Marisol Ballestero, vive en el barrio Blas de Lezo en la ciudad de Cartagena, tiene 2 hijas de 19 y 13 años que son su máxima motivación: con su amor, dedicación y  trabajo constante, ella sola  ha logrado sacarlos adelante con su negocio de confecciones; cuando inició esta actividad lo hizo como un pasatiempo, pero al separarse  de sus esposo la necesidad la obligó a fortalecerla, empezó  buscando mercado en diferentes colegios de Cartagena, su gestión y la calidad de sus productos, la llevaron a conseguir contratos con entidades educativas, vecinas y empleadas de empresas de la ciudad a quien en la actualidad vende ropa en diversas líneas, es así como le solicitan vestidos enteros, uniformes, blusas, pantalones y elegantes  diseños.  
Marisol  le da gracias a Dios por el don maravilloso que tiene para  desarrollar este oficio, su creatividad  se hace notoria en cada diseño pues le agrega mucho amor. Inició  en la confección desde el año  2.006 con esta actividad ha proporcionado la posibilidad cubrir  las necesidades de sus hijos: alimentación,  estudios, vestidos, diversión, es decir las propias de una familia y también ha podido comprar todo lo que necesita en casa para un mejor vivir;  Este es el segundo crédito que ha recibido con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el anterior  compro materia prima y amplió su cobertura de clientes, accediendo a nuevos mercados domésticos e institucionales  con los que tiene contrato.  Definitivamente su negocio ha cambiado su vida  pues con él tiene un trabajo, una gran satisfacción personal y puede ofrecer  a sus hijos un mejor nivel de vida. En la actualidad aplica a un crédito por valor de $ 2.000.000 que será invertido en la compra de materia prima  e insumos para la elaboración de uniformes de diarios y educación física de los colegios con los cuales tiene contratos y los pedidos de los diferentes clientes que ella tiene en los barrios de la ciudad
 El sueño de Marisol es ver su negocio crecer gradualmente; mas adelante comprar maquinarias industriales, tener operarias que también generen ingresos a sus familia, ofrecer sus servicios a muchas personas   que no conocen su producto y ser reconocida en la ciudad y a mas largo plazo  ampliarse a en diversas ciudades del país representando a Colombia.  Otra de sus  metas es ver a sus hijos   profesionales por que considera que es la mejor herencia que puede dejarle  y  también sueña  con tener su casa propia.  Su mayor dificultad fue enfrentar la vida sola con sus dos hijos pero da gracias a Dios pudo salir adelante, hoy se siente feliz y realizada sabiendo que les ha brindado todo lo necesario  y   enseñado que la vida no es fácil pero que con esfuerzo, dedicación y mucho amor se logran todos los propósitos. 
.
texts.en:
Marisol Ballestero lives in the Blas de Lezo neighborhood in the city of Cartagena. She has two daughters, 19 and 13 years old. They are her biggest motivation. With love, dedication, and constant work she, by herself, has gotten them ahead with her seamstress business. When she started this activity she did it as a pastime. But, upon separating from her husband, necessity obligated her to make it more than a passtime. She started looking for a market in the different schools in Cartagena. Her effort and the quality of her products helped her get contracts with different educational entities, neighbors, and business employees in the city. She currently sells a diverse line of clothes to them. They ask for complete outfits, uniforms, blouses, pants, and elegant designs. Marisol thanks God for the marvelous gift that she has to do this work. Her creativity is evident in each design; she adds lots of love. She started making clothes in 2006. This work gives her the opportunity of covering her children’s necessities; food, education, clothes, and entertainment. In addition to covering the family costs, she has been able to buy everything she needs in the house for a better life. This is the second loan that she has received from the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. With the previous loan she bought raw material and increased her customers. She accessed new domestic markets and institutions, and she has contracts with them. Her business has definitely changed her life. With the business she has work, great personal satisfaction, and she is able to give her children a better standard of living. She is currently applying for a loan for 2,000,000 COP. She will buy raw material and supplies to make uniforms for everyday and for physical education for the school that she has contracts with and for orders from different customers that she has in the neighborhoods in the city. Marisol’s dream is to see her business gradually grow. Later, she would buy industrial machines and have workers operate them, which would generate income for their families. She would offer her services to a lot of people who do not know her products and be recognized in the city. In the long term she would expand into different cities in the country and represent Colombia. Another one of her goals is to see her children become professionals because she considers that to be the best legacy that she can give them. She also dreams of having her own house. The biggest difficulty that she has is facing life alone with her two children. But, she thanks God that she was able to get ahead. Now she is happy and fulfilled knowing that she has given them everything they need and taught them that life is not easy. But, with effort, dedication, and much love they can achieve all of their goals.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw material and supplies to make uniforms for everyday and for physical education and for custom orders

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buying grocery products for resale

loans.name: The Lord's People Group

texts.en:
Helen F. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called The Lord’s People. In the photo, Helen is the one holding the sign. She is 38 years old, married, and has two children who are 3 and 5 years old.

For four years, Helen has been selling lapa, a traditional West African cloth, at the E.L.W.A. Rock Hole Market. She communicates well with her customers, which keeps them coming back.

Helen plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 34,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more lapa. Her goal is to grow her business and to be healthy.


About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more lapa to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of a pump

loans.name: :  Julio Ariel

texts.es:
Julio T. Martínez, Labora como Higienista en el Mercado Candelaria de Managua.
