While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Felicidad A..

Felicidad is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Felicidad owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Felicidad has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $65 a month from this activity.

In 2007, Felicidad joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Felicidad has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Felicidad is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products. This will be her 7th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose P. is currently in the business of selling alcohol and onions and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of onions to sell.  Rose is 39 years old and is a widow. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build houses for renting.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Nicole Aman

texts.fr: A. Nicole Aman est née le 16 Avril 1963 à Ouidah, une ville historique du Bénin. Il y a environs 19 ans que Nicole Aman s'est installée à Gbodjè dans la communne d'Abomey Calavi. Mariée à SOUSSIA Jonas, un maçon, Nicole Aman est mère de cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Nicole Aman vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Nicole Aman n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour assurer les différentes charges qui lui incombent, Nicole Aman vend depuis une dizaine d'année, du maïs (en gros et en détail) à son domicile. Nicole Aman achète ses produits à Parakou au Nord du Bénin. La demande de sa clientèle se fait de plus en plus nombreuse, et Nicole Aman n'arrive plus à la satisfaire, compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle et se faire plus de revenu, Nicole Aman sollicite pour la première fois, de crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Nicole Aman was born on April 16, 1963 in Ouidah, a historic village in Benin. About nineteen years ago, she settled in Gbodjè in the town of Abomey Calavi. Married to SOUSSIA Jonas, a mason, she is the mother of five children who are all in school. She lives together with her children and husband. The couple jointly ensures that family expenses are covered. Nicole Aman attended primary school only. To cover the different expenses incumbent upon her, she has sold corn (wholesale and retail) out of her home for about ten years. She buys her goods in Parakou in northern Benin. The demands of her customers are increasing more and more, and she is no longer able to satisfy them, given the few financial means she has at her disposal. To satisfy her customers and to have more income, she's requesting a loan from ALIDé for the first time.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying eight 100-kg sacks of corn

loans.name: Malak

texts.en: Malak is a 49-year-old widow with two unemployed children. After the death of her husband, she started working as a home-based tailor because she had fifteen years of experience in this occupation. She is the only provider for her family, so she works hard to make a good profit. Today, Malak is asking to borrow $800 to buy a new sewing machine to replace her old one in order to offer a good quality of work to her clients.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Charito's Group

texts.en:
Charito C. is from the village of Villa Corazon. She is 52 years old. Charito is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Charito is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Charito owns and operates a furniture-making business. She makes and sells general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Charito has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $220 a month from these activities.

In 2006, Charito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Charito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Charito is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product line. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Teresita

Teresita B. is from the village of Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. She is 59 years old. Teresita is married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $44 whenever she sells her animals.

In 2005, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 7th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Working on a freelance basis, he manages part of the housing projects in his town and its surroundings. With the help of the $1,000 loan he requested, he managed to expand his business by buying tools and a compressor to offer a better quality of service to his clients.

Arlene is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product line. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline A. is 56 years old. She works in the Grand Marché de Hédzranawoé, selling a variety of vegetables. In this busy location, Ms. A. is able to serve many customers. This will be her first loan with WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock of vegetables. She is single and has one child. With this loan, Ms. A. will be better able to support both her business and her family.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
In her house, Felicia, 38, sells sarongs and drinks at retail prices to her customers. With over 12 years of experience, she is now ready to expand her business. The mother of five children, three boys and two girls, Felicia is married to a government worker who also supports the home. 

Very happy and grateful to all Kiva lenders for their support in alleviating their financial stress, she hopes for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders in anticipation of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Gerlie's Group

texts.en:
Gerlie G., from the village of Bagong Tanza, is the 40-year-old group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

A married mother of five school-aged children, Gerlie's main income is derived from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables to sell. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Gerlie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise, Gerlie is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will her sixth from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana, a 25-year-old married woman and mother of one child, has been working in home-based clothing sales since 2004, receiving clients at her home where she presents the clothes. With her business income, she is able to cooperate with her husband in the household and to satisfy her child's needs.

Since she always tries to offer new clothes and collections to her clients, Diana is requesting a loan of $1,200 to expand her inventory for the new season and present a larger choice of clothes to her clients.

loans.use: To expand her inventory for the new season

loans.name: Islom

texts.ru: Зухуров Ислом проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 47 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка а дети учатся. Отец, пенсионер. Сам Ислом имеет высшее образование. Он Более 20 лет работает по специальности ветеринаром. Ислом в основном лечит жывотных. Кредит берет для закупа лекарств и вакцины.
texts.en:
Z. Islom lives in the Shahrituz region. He’s forty-seven years old, married and has five children. His wife stays at home, his children go to school and his father is retired. Islom has a university education. For more than twenty years he has worked as a veterinarian, usually treating only animals. He’s asking for a loan in order to buy medication and vaccines.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Закуп лекарств и вакцины

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Parum

She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a big shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Badiha

texts.en:
Badiha is a 37-year-old married woman with eight children of whom three are still going to school.

In 2005, Badiha decided to open a new business to help her husband to raise her eight children. She started working in clothing sales after seeing a need for such services in the region. She prepared a special room in her house for this purpose and started receiving clients.

Today, Badiha is grateful for her business and she needs to borrow $1,000 to expand her work by buying more clothes to make a bigger profit.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr: Née en 1974 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, S. Elisabeth est mariée à KOTCHA Paul, un chauffeur. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille s'est installée au quartier Bazounkpa à Cococodji dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, depuis 5 ans. Elisabeth assure avec son mari, les  différentes charges de la famille. Elisabeth n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a près de 4 ans que Elisabeth a commencé la vente de divers produits (conserves de tomate, savons, sucre, piles, pâtes alimentaire, lait en poudre, bougies, riz, etc.) dans une barraque à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Elisabeth se ravitaille. Elisabeth désire renforcer son capital et élever le niveau de son activité, afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle et de se faire plus de revenu. C'est pour cette raison que Elisabeth sollicite une première fois, de crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1974 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. S. Elisabeth is married to Mr. KOTCHA Paul, a chauffeur. The couple has four children who are all in school. Five years ago, the family settled in the Bazounkpa district in Cococodji, in the town of Abomey Calavi. Along with her husband, Elisabeth ensures that the different family expenses are covered. Elisabeth did not go to school. Almost four years ago, she stated selling a variety of goods (canned tomatoes, soaps, sugar, batteries, pasta, powdered milk, candles, rice, etc.) in a shed at her home. Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she goes to resupply herself. She would like to boost her capital and to raise her business level in order to responder better to customer demands and to bring in more revenues. For these reasons, she is requesting a loan from ALIDé for the first time.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying three baskets of tomatoes, a box of sugar, a box of powdered milk, pasta

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en:
Mostafa is a 28-year-old single man. After graduating from university with a computer major, he opened a computer shop in 2005. He’s specialized in selling and repairing computers and his business has developed remarkably over the years.

Today, Mostafa needs to enlarge his business and he's asking to borrow $1,200 to buy a number of used computers at good prices. He will repair and sell them to make a good income.

loans.use: To buy a number of used computers

loans.name: Christina

texts.en: Christina P. is currently in the business of selling local alcohol beverages at home and is requesting a loan to stock more materials to use and make more alcohol to sell. Christina is 24 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a big hotel (restaurant). About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more materials to use to make more alcohol to sell

loans.name: Bolale

texts.en:
Bolale lives in Lagos State where she sells loaves of bread and drinks at retail prices to her customers. With over twenty years of experience in sales, she is very willing to expand her business. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.

Bolale has five children: three males and two females. She is 50 years old and married. Although she is advanced in age, she is energetic and optimistic about the future of her business and that of her family. She hopes to make more profits that will enable her to purchase a plot of land where she can build her own house.

Bolale hopes for a loan of NGN 160,000 to purchase more loaves of bread and drinks to sell. She says thank you in anticipation to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more loaves of bread and drinks to sell

loans.name: Akayévi

texts.en:
Akayévi A. is 27 years old, is single, and does not have children. She works selling pre-paid cellphone cards in Lomé, Togo. She is the sole employee of her business which she began in 2005.

Ms. A. is now asking for her second loan from WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock of cellphone cards.

loans.use: To purchase more pre-paid cellphone cards

loans.name: Badawi

texts.en:
Badawi has owned a car repair shop in his town since 2004. He’s a 23-year-old single man living with his family.

Badawi specializes in car painting and bodywork repair. He has great demand for his shop and thus he wants to buy more spare parts and tools in order to continue to be in demand by his clients.

Badawi wants to take out a loan of $1,200 to buy more tools and to enlarge his shop to meet the requirement of his clients and make a good income.

loans.use: To buy new tools for his shop and more spare parts

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en: Marilou J. is from the village of Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 7 years old, is married, and has seven school-aged children. Marilou owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling ready to wear items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of relatives and other family members. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate is a happy woman; she sells secondhand clothes in her shop in the market in Lagos State. She is married and her husband is a businessman. Kate is 40 years old and she has three children: two males and one female. Her children are still dependent on her and they attend school.

Kate hopes to own a boutique in the future. She needs the loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more secondhand clothes to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more materials that will be used to make shoes

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 40-year-old single man. He has been working for the past 12 years in the business of producing cleaning products and detergents. He's well known in the whole region where he distributes his products to the shops and he sells also to individual clients upon their request. Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow $1,200 USD to buy merchandise needed such as raw materials and plastic bottles to increase his sales and therefore his income.

loans.use: buy merchandise needed such as raw materials and plastic bottles

loans.name: Yao

texts.en: Yao D. was born in Accra, Ghana and is a trained cobbler. He now lives in Lomé, Togo selling ice water and ice cubes. He began this business in 2008 and is now asking for his first loan from WAGES. He will use this loan to purchase water for freezing. Mr. D. is 39 years old, married and has three children.  Please help Mr. D. keep his customers cool and hydrated.

loans.use: Purchase and resale of water and ice

Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing is business oriented; with her last Kiva loan she rented a shop and bought more foodstuffs and sachet water (water in plastic bags) in addition to her ice-cube production. She has been in this business for a long time.

Blessing has three children and she is 33 years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they attend school. She is very determined to lift her family out of poverty and wants to make more money so that she can build her own house. She wants her children to have a very bright future by giving them the best education.

Blessing hopes for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and sachet water to sell. She duly appreciates all Kiva lenders who would be providing her with this financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and sachet water to sell

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria A. is currently in the business of selling groundnut (peanut) paste and tomatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more groundnuts to make paste to sell. Maria is 25 years old and is married to a soldier. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house that includes a shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Berthe

texts.fr: Née en 1965 dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, A. Berthe vit depuis près de 40 ans dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Berthe est mariée à TOKPANOU Jacques, un employé au Port de Cotonou, la capitale économique du Bénin. Berthe a six enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Tous les enfants vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Berthe vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les différentes charges de la famille. C'est une jardinière qui vend ses légumes au marché de Ganhi à Cotonou, et les livre également aux revendeuses. Berthe achète les graines qu'elle sème à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Berthe exerce cette activité depuis 20 ans environs, et a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé et qui lui a permis de renforcer un peu son activité. Berthe ambitionne agrandir son jardin et vendre en gros ses légumes, ce qui lui permettra d'accroître son revenu et de faire face à ses besoins. C'est pourquoi Berthe sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1965 in the town of Abomey Calavi, Ms. A. Berthe has lived there for forty years. She is married to Mr. TOKPANOU Jacques, an employee at the Port of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Berthe has six children, of whom some are in school. All of the children live together with their parents. Berthe helps out her husband where it concerns the different family expenses. She is a gardener who sells her vegetables at the Ganhi market in Cotonou and who also delivers them to retailers. Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she buys seeds for planting. She has been in this business for about twenty years and has already obtained an ALIDé loan, which she has repaid. It enabled her to build up her business a little. Berthe has the ambition of expanding her garden and selling her vegetables in bulk. This will enable her to increase her revenues and to address her needs. She is requesting a second loan from ALIDé for these reasons.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 8 sacks of manure and 5 sacks of seeds

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: Merlinda A. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 54 years old, is married, and has eight adult children. Merlinda owns and operates a specialized retail store selling ready to wear items like shirts , shoes, and pants in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Merlinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Merlinda is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 24-year-old single man living with his parents and one sister. He has been working for the past eight years as an elevator technician. He works on a freelance basis upon request of his clients, taking new projects and repairing elevators.

Mohamad is the only provider for his family because his father stopped working after becoming old and sick. Today, Mohamad is requesting $1,000 to buy new tools needed for his work because he's planning to expand his business and take on more projects.

loans.use: To buy new tools for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase medicine in bulk

loans.name: Ayak

texts.en:
Ayak R. is currently in the business of selling food at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more foodstuffs to be cooked and sold. Ayak is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a cattle keeper. She has six children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a big hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to be cooked and sold

loans.name: Amale

texts.en: Amale is a 47-year-old single woman living with her mother. She is the only one who takes care of her mother. She has been working as a farmer for the past 15 years. She learned this occupation from her father because her region specializes in this occupation. She cultivates all types of vegetables and she distributes her products to the market to be sold. Today, Amale is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase agriculturA. supplies such as seed, fertilizers and some tools to be prepared for the summer cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase agriculture supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase charcoal in bulk.

loans.name: Onyinye

texts.en: Onyinye is a peaceful and hard-working woman. She lives in Lagos state. She sells drinks and cooked food in her shop. She cooks mouth-watering Nigerian foods for her customers. She is married with five children. Her children are still in primary school and she hopes they become graduates in the future. Onyinye has a lot of responsibility. That is why she is very optimistic about the prosperity of her business and that of her family. She is 34 years old and her husband is a businessman. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and to sell. She says thank you to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell.

loans.name: Modou Dame

texts.fr: Monsieur Modou Dame F. est agent de sécurité âgé de 30 ans. Il pratique également  l’embouche bovine et  le transport de taxi clando pendant ses heures libres. Il est  depuis 2009 membre de U-IMCEC Bambey, une ville située à 120 Kms de Dakar la capitale du Sénégal. Cependant, Monsieur F., voulant augmenter ses revenus, demande un prêt de 150 000 FCFA  pour completer son capital consacré à acheter un bœuf et un mouton de race pour relancer son embouche.
texts.en:
Mr. Modou Dame F., aged 30, is a security guard. He also fattens cattle and operates an unofficial taxi during his free time. Since 2009, he has been a member of U-IMCEC of Bambey, a city located 120 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. Yet wanting to augment his revenues, Mr. F. is asking for a loan of 150,000 francs CFA to round out the capital he has set aside for buying a cow and a type of sheep in order to renew his work in husbandry.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a cow and a sheep

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr: Monsieur Adama N. âgé de 42 ans est membre d’U-IMCEC  Bambey une ville située à 120 Kms de Dakar,  la capitale du Sénégal. Il est agent de sécurité, mais aussi s’active dans le commerce depuis 2000.  Monsieur Adama N. est marié et père d’un enfant âgé de 4 ans. Cependant sa femme est atteinte d’une maladie le goitre et elle doit être opérée dans les prochains jours.   C’est ainsi que Monsieur N. introduit une demande de prêt à la caisse. Il sollicite un montant de 125 000 FCFA pour assurer les frais de l’opération de sa femme.
texts.en:
Mr. Adama N., aged 42, is a member of U-IMCEC of Bambey, a city located 120 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. He is a security guard, but he has also been active in commerce since 2000. He is married and the father of a 4-year-old child. However, his wife suffers from goiter, and she must have an operation in the coming days. This is why Mr. N. is presenting a request for a loan to the bank. He is requesting an amount of 125,000 francs CFA to make sure the costs are covered for his wife's operation.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Medical expenses for his wife

loans.name: Lacan Kwite A Aol Daina Group

texts.en: A. Daina is a 38-year-old business woman who is married with three children all going to school.  She also has other dependents, so she has a total of six going to school. She has a charcoal business which she has been running for over six years. She is using the loan to grow her business by purchasing 60 bags of charcoal and selling them at the Layibi and Gulu markets. Before getting the loan, having 60 bags was unheard of. She now has peace of mind. She is an active and hardworking woman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To grow her business by purchasing 60 bags of charcoal

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios O. is from the village of Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 64 years old. Remedios is married and has five adult-age children. To make a living, Remedios owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop which sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Remedios joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Remedios from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Anai

texts.en:
Anai J. is currently in the business of selling milk in a market and is requesting a loan to purchase more jerrycans of milk to sell. Anai is 24 years old and married to a farmer. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more cows.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more jerrycans of milk to sell

loans.name: Samah

texts.en:
Samah has sold clothes and accessories from her house since 2006. She is 30 years old, married and has three children who still go to school. She cooperates with her husband in the household. She's thankful for her small business; it allows her to provide better living conditions for her family. 

Today, Samah is requesting to borrow $1,100 to purchase additional clothes and accessories to attract more clients to her shop in order to enlarge her business in the coming months and have higher profits.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothes and accessories

loans.name: Edwige Akouavi

texts.fr: L. Edwige Akouavi est née le 16 Octobre 1974 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Edwige Akouavi s'est installée à Akadjamey dans la commune d'Abomey calavi. Mariée à GODONOU Périn, un militaire, Edwige Akouavi n'a pas encore d'enfant, mais a un enfant à charge. La famille vit ensemble à Akadjamey. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Edwige Akouavi n'a fait que l'école primaire. C'est une jardinière qui livre ses légumes aux revendeuses. Edwige Akouavi achète les graines et les engrais à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est depuis 5 ans que Edwige Akouavi mène cette activité, et a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Edwige Akouavi a bien remboursé le premier crédit, et sollicite un deuxième crédit en vue de développer son jardin et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, ce qui lui permettra d'avoir plus de revenu.
texts.en:
L. Edwige Akouavi was born on October 16, 1974 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. About ten years ago, she settled in Akadjamey, in the town of Abomey Calavi. Married to GODONOU Périn, a soldier, she still has no children, but she supports a child. The family lives together in Akadjamey. The couple jointly ensure that family expenses are covered. Edwige Akouavi attended primary school only. She is a gardener who delivers her vegetables to retailers. She buys seeds and fertilizer at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been in this business for five years and has already had a loan from ALIDé. She repaid her first loan and is requesting a second one for developing her garden and satisfying her customers further. This will allow her to earn more income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 5 sacks of manure and 5 sacks of seeds

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en:
Kehinde lives in Lagos state. She sells groceries, drinks and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She is happily married and her husband is a pastor. She is without a child. 

She is very enthusiastic about the growth of her business; that is why she hopes for a loan of 90,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk

loans.name: Haytham

texts.en: Haytham is a 22-year-old single man. He started working when he was very young. He has been repairing computers and maintaining electronic equipment to help improve his living conditions as well as business abilities and activities. He has been involved in this occupation since 2004. With the income from his business, he is able to support his father. Today, Haytham is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy new tools to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy new tools

loans.name: Agbeguida

texts.en: Agbeguida G. is 36 years old and runs a hardware store called “ETS. Mon Seigneur” in Lomé, Togo. Mr. G. is married and has two children. He began his business in 2000 and is asking for his second loan from WAGES, which he will use to replenish his stock of nails, paints and other hardware supplies. With your help, Mr. G.’s business will continue to grow.

loans.use: To restock hardware supplies

loans.name: Lacan Kwite A Betty Pasca Ojok Group

texts.en: Betty P. O. is the group president of Lacan Kwite A.  She is a hard-working married woman who is 50 years old and blessed with five children. All of her children, as well as two other dependents, are in school. She has a produce business which she has been operating for over twenty-two years. She will use her loan to purchase more produce to meet her cusotmers’ demands, such as beans, maize, simsim (sesame), ground nuts, and so forth. Her business is expanding, and she hopes to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to help educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more produce to meet her customers' demands

loans.name: Samira

texts.en: Samira is a 43-year-old married woman. A mother of 5 children, she works as a home-based tailor to help her husband with the family's income. She has been involved in this business for the past 30 years. With her long experience, she has become well known throughout the whole region. Today, Samira is requesting a loan of $1,200 to replace her old sewing machine with a new one so she can continue to work properly and always satisfy the needs of her clients.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fish in bulk

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina is a 33-year-old married woman. She has four unemployed children. She has been working since 2005, selling all types of lingerie. She presents her products at her home in addition to selling through moving around and upon the request of her clients. Lina helps her husband with her limited income to support the heavy needs of life. 

Today, Lina is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy more merchandise to attract more clients to her products and augment her sales and profits.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Marta

texts.en:
Marta D. is currently in the business of selling bread in the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of sugar to sell. Marta is 25 years old and is married to a policeman. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of sugar to sell

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna B. is from the village of Libertad, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Lorna is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over  years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Lorna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anene

texts.en:
Anene sells sarongs, hair gear and bags in her retail shop. She is married with four children who are in primary and secondary schools. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. They live in Lagos State. 

With over 14 years of experience in sales, Anene is very willing to expand her business. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is very concerned about the growth of her business and the upkeep of her family. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more sarongs and bags to sell. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and bags to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more kuku (chicken) feed and drugs.

loans.name: Mrs. Leng Dul Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 20 people who live in Trapeang Angk village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Leng D., 42 years old, is a village bank president who has been selected by all the members. She is a mother of four children, two of whom are weavers, while the others attend the local public school. She is a weaver and her husband Mr. Loung Srey is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he cultivates rice to support his family’s living.

In the rice field, they have a problem because it is infertile soil, but they did not have enough money to support it. So in order to improve her family’s living conditions, Mrs. Leng D. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer for the field.

All the members are in the picture but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Albertine Kossiba

texts.fr: Née en 1967 à Abomey Calavi au Bénin, B. Albertine Kossiba est mariée à CADJA Eugène, un mécanicien. Le couple a cinq enfants à charge, dont quatre sont leurs propres enfants. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. Il y a 18 ans environs que Albertine Kossiba s'est installée au quartier Gbodjè dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, où elle vit avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Albertine Kossiba n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses différents besoins, Albertine Kossiba vend des condiments (tomates fraîches, piments, oignons, etc.) et divers autres produits (huile de palme, boîtes de lait, sucre, poissons fumés, etc.) dans une barraque size à son domicile. Albertine Kossiba s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Albertine Kossiba mène cette activité depuis 8 ans, et a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé et qui lui a permis d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. La clientèle de Albertine Kossiba s'agrandit au jour le jour et elle n'arrive plus à satisfaire tous ses clients, compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose. C'est pour cette raison que Albertine Kossiba sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1967 in the town of Abomey Calavi in Benin, B. Albertine Kossiba is married to Cadja Eugene, a mechanic. The couple has five children in their care, four of whom are their own children. Some of the children are attending school. For the past 18 years, Albertine Kossiba has lived in the neighborhood of Gbodjè in the town of Abomey Calavi, where she lives with her husband and their children. Together, the couple takes care of the needs of the family. Albertine Kossiba was not able to attend school. In order to handle her clients' varying needs, Albertine Kossiba sells condiments (fresh tomatoes, hot peppers, onions, etc.) and various other products (palm oil, cans of milk, sugar, smoked fish, etc.) in a booth in her house. Albertine Kossiba supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Albertine Kossiba has been doing this business for 8 years and has already had one loan with Alidé, a loan which was fully repaid and which enabled her to increase her sales. Albertine Kossiba's clientèle is growing everyday and she cannot satisfy all of her clients, given the small financial means she has at her disposal. It is for this reason that Albertine Kossiba is requesting a second loan with Alidé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 2 crates of tomatoes, 2 crates of onions and hot peppers, milk and sugar.

loans.name: Maha

texts.en:
Maha is a 25-year-old married woman and mother of 2 children.

In 2005 Maha started working as a hairdresser receiving clients at her home where she had prepared a special room for this purpose. She really likes her job and she always tries to learn the new haircuts to be up-to-date.

Today Maha is requesting to borrow $1200 to buy merchandise such as a hair colors, hair accessories and supplies to satisfy the needs of her clients.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her hair salon.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice, beans, maize in bulk.

loans.name: Fernando

texts.pt:
Fernando João tem 48 anos de idade é solteiro pai de 3 filhos com idades compreendidas entre os 6 aos 14 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Para alem dos seus filhos responsabiliza se pelas suas duas sobrinhas que vivem com ele em sua casa e consegue poupar por mes 1.000.00mt.

Sai de Nampula para Maputo emissão de serviço começa a trabalha na mecânica e serralharia durante 5 anos consequentemente é recrutado para cumprir o serviço militar obrigatório. Após 6 anos ele é desmobilizado e passa a viver com seu irmão na vila de namaacha na fronteira da Suazilândia, após sua chegada continua com seus trabalhos de Mecânica e serralharia. Anos depois com o fundo colectado nos seus trabalhos ele inicia com a criação de pintos primeiramente com uma caixa e meia (1500x100) assim aproxima se hluvuku solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 6.000.00mt para reforçar o volume do seu negocio. Hoje e um dos melhores criadores da região tem comprado uma media de 100x3caixas de pintos gastando 24.000.00mt em cada fase, tem tido um lucro mensal no valor de 9.000.00mt caso não haja mortalidades.

Este é o segundo empréstimo de Fernando na hluvuku e primeiro com kiva. O primeiro de 6.000.00mt foi usado para aumentar a criação de pintos, este segundo de 15.000.00mt será usado para mesma finalidade. Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para ampliação das suas capoeiras.
texts.en:
Fernando João is 48 years old and is a single father of 3 children ages 6 to 14, all of whom attend school. In addition to his children he supports his two nieces who live with him. He manages to save 1.000.00 MT per month. He left Nampula for Maputo and worked as a mechanic and locksmith for 5 years. He was then conscripted to serve his mandatory military service. After 6 years he was discharged and went to live with his brother in Vila de Namaacha on the border of Swaziland. He again worked as a mechanic and locksmith. Years later, with funds saved from his work, he started raising chickens, starting with a box and a half (1500x100) of chicks and approached Hluvuku to request a loan for 6.000.00 MT to increase the volume of his business. Today he is one of the best chicken farmers in the region and has purchased an average of 100x3 boxes of chicks at a cost of 24.000.00 MT in each phase. He has monthly earnings around 9.000.00 when none of the chicks die. This is Fernando's second loan with Hluvuku and his first with Kiva. The first loan for 6.000.00 MT was used to grow his business raising chickens. This second loan for 15.000.00 MT will be used for the same purpose. He is confident that he will repay the loan before it is due and request a new loan to expand his chicken coops.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and selling chickens

loans.name: Majed

texts.en: Majed is an 18-year-old man living with his family. He has been working as a home painter since 2007. He started this occupation as his own business and to start a new career. During these 2 years, he has been able to have a good start and find a good number of clients. Today, Majed is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to buy a compressor and scafolding to expand his business and began taking on bigger projects and having more clients.

loans.use: buy a compressor and scafolding

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tomatoes, oil, rice and dried fish in bulk

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en: JalA. has owned a car electricA. systems repair shop in his town since 2005. He’s 23 years old and single. This young man caters to a wide range of clientele in his village and surrounding neighborhoods.  He has a great demand for his shop because he's very talented in his occupation and clients trust him. That’s why he is asking to borrow US$ 1,200 to buy more tools because his business operation is remarkably developed. He wants to better satisfy the needs of his clients.

loans.use: buy more tools

loans.name: Suliamon

texts.en: Suliamon sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. Because of her years of experience in her business, she is able to attract and retain more customers. She hopes to own a shopping mall in the future. She is happily married with 2 children and her husband is a commercial driver who also supports the home. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase  oil, beans, tomatoes, and onions in bulk

loans.name: Kosowoa

texts.en: Kosowoa N. sells cement, charcoal and hardware products in Lomé, Togo. She is married and has 3 children. Mrs. N. has over ten years of experience in this field. She opened her business in 1998 and is now asking for her fourth loan from WAGES. She will use a third of this loan to replenish her stock of hardware products and use the remainder to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal and hardware

loans.name: Mekhriniso

texts.ru: Муминова Мехринисо проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 41 год. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Муж, занимается животноводством. Дети, учатся. Сама Мехринисо торгует более 5 лет. У нее собственный магазин, где она в основном продает продукты питания и другие нужные для хозяйства вещи. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота. Мехринисо хочет расширить свой бизнес. Она намерена на втором этаже своего магазина открыт интернет кафе.
texts.en:
Mekhriniso M. lives in the Hamadoni region. She is 41 years old. She is married and has three children. Her husband does animal husbandry. Her children study. Mekhriniso has been in sales for more than five years. She has own store where she mostly sells food and other home necessities. She is taking out a loan to increase sales. Mekhriniso wants to expand her business. She plans to open an internet cafe on the second floor of her store.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase vitenge and kanga in bulk

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en: Mostafa is a 48-year-old married man with 5 children, 2 of whom are still unemployed. In 2005, he started working as a taxi driver, servicing his town and its surroundings. He also arranges private transportation upon client request in order to make extra money. Today, Mostafa is requesting a $1,200 loan to renew his car with needed maintenance and painting in order to activate his business and present a good quality of service to his clients to earn income.

loans.use: maintenance and painting for his vehicle

loans.name: Durowoju

texts.en: Durowoju sells foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for the past 6 years. Durowoju lives in Lagos state. She is 38 years old and married with 5 dependent children, all of whom go to school. She is very determined to pull her family and business out of poverty. Her husband is a pastor and he also supports the family. Durowoju hopes to expand her business by opening another shop in the future. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more veterinary drugs

loans.name: Elise

texts.fr: Née en 1971 au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, A. Elise est mariée à AKUESON Laurent, un mécanicien. Elise est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. Elise vit depuis 18 ans environs à Womey, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Elise n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Elise mène comme activité, la vente de condiments de sauce (tomates, piments, oignons) ainsi que du poisson fumé à son domicile. Elise s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo. Elise mène cette activité depuis 8 ans environs et a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé et qui lui a permis d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. Elise sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de se faire plus de revenu. Elise ambitionne plus tard, diversifier son activité par la vente de produits vivriers.
texts.en:
Born in 1971 in Togo, the country next to Benin, A. Elise is married to Akueson Laurent, a mechanic. Elise is the mother of three children, all of whom are attending school. The couple has another child in their care, in addition to their own children. For the past 18 years, Elise has lived around Womey, in the town of Abomey Calavi, with her husband and their children. The couple takes care of the needs of their family together. Elise did not attend very much school. In order to handle the needs of her children, Elise has a business selling condiments (tomatoes, hot peppers, onions) and smoked fish from her home. Elise supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and from Lomé in Togo. Elise has done this business for about 8 years and has already benefitted from one loan from Alidé, a loan which she fully repaid and helped her grow her income. Elise is requesting a second loan with Alidé, with which she intends to grow her stock and also her revenue. Ultimately, Elise aims to diversify her business by selling a variety of crops.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 2 crates of fresh tomatoes, 1 crate of hot peppers and 2 crates of fish.

loans.name: Aina

texts.en:
Aina sells clothes, shoes and bags in her shop at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for the past two years. She hopes to own a world class boutique in the future.

Aina is single and without children. She hopes to get married soon. She is 32 years old.

Aina hopes for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more clothes and bags to sell. She has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Aina says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Assoupevi

texts.en:
Assoupevi G. sells fabrics and cloth for dressmaking in Lomé, Togo. She is married to a tennis instructor and they have two children.

Mrs. G. has been running her business from home since 1988 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to restock her supply of colorful fabrics used to make dresses, shirts and head wraps. With the profits, she will continue to support her family and her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fabric and cloth

loans.name: Salome Marcos

texts.pt:
Salomé marcos M. nasceu em Gaza tem 44 anos de idade, é solteira mãe de 2 filhas com idades compriendidas entre os 24 aos 25 anos de idade nenhuma das duas se encontra a estudar pois trabalham todas juntas. Para alem das suas filhas responsabiliza se pelos seus 4 netos que vivem com ela em sua casa e consegue poupar por mes 2.000.00mt. 

Salome estudou até a 4 classe porque a escola onde frequentava terminava naquele nivel de escolaridade, então seu professor leva a ela alegando que ia arranjar uma vaga numa outra escola e este abusa dela (violação de menores) e este a engravida. Salomé fica desesperada com a situação pois a sua mãe manda lhe embora de casa. Sai de Gaza para vila de namaacha na fronteira de Suazilândia com sua amiga a procura de emprego, após sua chegada começa a trabalhar no governo do distrito como servente, mas devido a doença do século (HIV+) ela teve que abandonar o emprego porque sofria descriminação.

Anos depois começa a trabalhar com plantas de varias espécies tais como (Azáleas, Antores e Catos) pois são fáceis de se multiplicar e apreciáveis pois ela é uma florista de mão cheia e cultiva um lindo jardim em sua casa. Hoje Salomé e uma das mais famosas na região, vendendo flores para clientes da capital Maputo ganhando por mes aproximadamente 10.000.00mt porque para alem de vender tem contratos de jardinagem com proprietários de quinta na vila.
 Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Salomé na hluvuku e kiva. O primeiro de 15.000.00mt foi usado para comprar insumos agrícolas tais como sementes e pesticidas para melhorar a sua colecção de flores, o segundo de 10.000.00 foi usado para aumentar a multiplicação das mesmas e estes 20.000.00mt serão usados para o mesmo fim. Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto pois conta com ajuda das suas duas filhas
texts.en:
Salomé Marcos M. was born in Gaza. She is 44 years old and is a single mother of two daughters aged 24 and 25. Neither of her daughters are in school as they work with her. In addition to her 2 daughters, she also supports her 4 grandchildren who live with them. She is able to save 2.000.00 MT per month. Salome attended school until the 4th grade because the school she attended ended at that level. Then her professor took her saying that he was going to arrange an opening at another school and he abused her (child rape) and she became pregnant. Salomé was desperate about the situation because her mother threw her out of the house. She left Gaza and moved to Vila de Namaacha on the border with Swaziland with a friend to look for work. After she arrived, she began to work for the governor of the district as a servant, but due to the illness of the century (AIDS) she had to leave her job because she faced discrimination. Years later she began working with plants of various species such as Azaelas, Antores and Cacti) because the reproduce easily and valuable. She is a talented florist and has a pretty garden at her house. Today Salomé is one of the most famous florists in the region, selling flowers for clients in the capital, Maputo, and earning approximately 10.000.00 MT per month because in addition to her sales she also has gardening contracts with property owners in town. This is Salomés third loan with Hluvuku and Kiva. The first loan for 15,000.00 MT was used to purchase agricultural products like seeds and pesticides to improve her flower collection. The second loan, for 10.000.00, was used to increase the reproduction of the same, and this 20.000.00 MT will also be used for the same purpose. She is confident that she will pay her loan before it is due since she has the help of her two daughters.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: reproduction and sale of plants and flowers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase beans, maize and rice in bulk

loans.name: Riad

texts.en:
Riad is a 35-year-old married man with two young children. He has been working as a home electrician since 2000. His wife also helps him in the household. Their only purpose is to provide better life conditions for the children in addition of advancing their children to the university.

Riad dreams of seeing his two children educated and having a good work in the future. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy a car for easier transport to the houses he works at.

loans.use: To buy a car for his business

loans.name: Adjo

texts.en:
Adjo P. sells onions and ginger in the Grand Marché de Lomé in Togo. She is married and has three children.

Mrs. P. began her business in this popular market in 2004. She is now asking for her first loan from WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock. With this loan, she will keep her display full and her customers satisfied.

loans.use: To purchase more onions and ginger to sell

loans.name: Helena Eduardo

texts.pt:
Helena nasceu em Gaza tem 42 anos de idade, é viúva mãe de dois filhos a primeira de 22 e o segundo de 20 anos o mais novo é que vai a escola, para além dos seus filhos responsabiliza se pelos seus dois netos que vivem com ela em sua casa. Consegue poupar por mês 1.000.00MT

Helena sai de Gaza quando seu marido é transferido para vila de Namaacha na Fronteira da Suazilândia como Guarda Fronteira. Anos depois seu esposo perde a vida deixando-a com dois filhos por criar, a vida fica muito difícil para Helena então seu genro da lhe um fundo para iniciar o seu próprio negócio. Dá inicio de um negócio de troca de latas vazias adquiridas na Capital Maputo e revendidas na fronteira, em troca ganhava lagerins, sandálias plásticas e cestos, fazia a revenda na capital e vice versa.

Seu negócio foi crescendo e resolve mudar de actividade, pois aquela era muito cansativo, em 2000 consegue arranjar uma banca no Mercado Central onde vende produtos de primeira necessidade. Tem como melhor produto amendoim, tomate, coco, e o óleo alimentar adquiridos na Swazilândia, o saco a 1.320.00MT a caixa a 500.00MT, o saco 500.00MT e a caixa a 450.00MT. Tem viajado duas vezes por semana porque para além de vender no Mercado Central tem vendido também no Mercado Informal (shoprite) nas quartas e sábados, tem um lucro de 3.000.00MT. 

Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Helena na Hluvuku e segundo com Kiva. O primeiro de 7.000 foi usado para recomeçar o seu negócio, o segundo de 8.000.00MT foi usado para aumentar o volume dos seus produtos. Estes 13.000.00MT serão usados para o mesmo fim esta confiante que vai reembolsar sem nenhum problema porque para além de ser negociante é secretaria do Bairro 25 de junho onde recebe algumas propinas em cada três meses, e pretende construir sua própria Barraca na sua residência.
texts.en:
Helena was born in Gaza. She is 42 years old and is a widowed mother of 2 sons, ages 22 and 20. Her younger son attends school. In addition to her sons she also supports two grandchildren who live with her. She is able to save 1.000.00 MT per month. Helena left Gaza when her husband was transferred to Vila de Namaacha on the border with Swaziland as part of the Border Patrol. Years later her husband died, leaving her with two children to raise. Life was very difficult for Helena. Then her son-in-law gave her money to start her own business. She started a business exchanging empty cans acquired in Maputo and reselling them on the border. In exchange she received lagerins, plastic sandals and baskets, which she resold in the capital and vice versa. Her business was growing and she decided to change activities, as that one was very tiring. In 2000 she was able to set up a booth in the Central Market where she sells basic goods. Her best products are peanuts, tomatoes, coconut, and cooking oil obtained in Swaziland for the following prices: a sack for 1.320.00 MT, a box for 500.00 MT, a sack for 500.00 MT and a box for 450.00 MT respectively. She travels twice a week because in addition to selling in the Central Market she sells in the Informal Market (shoprite) on Thursdays and Saturdays. She makes a profit of 3.000.00MT. This is Helena's third loan with Hluvuku and second with Kiva. The first loan for 7.000 was used to restart her business. The second for 8.000.00MT was used to purchase more merchandise. This 13.000.00 MT will be used for the same purpose. She is confident that she is going to pay back the loan without any problems. In addition to being a businesswoman she is the secretary of the Bairro 25 de junho neighborhood, for which she receives tips every three months, and she is hoping to build her own sales counter at her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of vegetables, grains, and other merchandise

loans.name: Nayef

texts.en: Nayef is a 23-year-old single man. He has 2004 done sanitary work; it’s related to repairing toilets, faucets etc. Nayef is very happy with his occupation and he's grateful for his revenue.  Nayef is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase a speciA. compressor for his work in addition of some tools because he's planning to take the step and enlarge his business by taking more projects and being known by a grand number of customers and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: purchase a special compressor for his work in addition of some tools

loans.name: Bahaa

texts.en: Bahaa has owned a beauty salon for women in his town since 2008 and has 11 years of experience in this occupation. He decided to be independent and works on his own after having his first child. He bought a new shop and makes the necessary décor and started receiving clients. He’s very convinced by this new step in his life. Today, Bahaa is requesting to borrow $1,200 to add new decor to his salon and buy more equipment and tools needed in order to complete the preparation of his salon and be in the requisition of his customers.

loans.use: add new decor to his salon and buy more equipment and tools

loans.name: 2 De Junio Group

texts.es:
El comité 2 de Junio se formo hace 2 gracias al interés de varias señoras, residentes en la Villa San Miguel, de Thompson. 
Así lo hicieron y lograron perdurar en el tiempo; mediante mucho sacrificio han logrado superar diversas situaciones. Son bastante unidas, se reunen todos los domingos en la casa de la coordinadora general quien es la señora Perla R.. 
En crédito que reciben estarán destinadas a la mejoras de las actividades a que se dedica cada una de las integrantes de la comisión en general en la compra de artículos que serán vendidos en sus respectivas actividades comerciales.
Así como la Sra. Perla quién posee una pequeña tienda donde vende todos los artículos de la canasta básica familiar como azúcar, fideos, arroz y otros.
Ella atiende su negocio con la ayuda de sus hijos quienes en su tiempo libre ya todos son estudiantes, se encargan de la atención ala cliente en la tienda.
Las actividades de las demás integrantes es como sigue: 

1
Perla R.
Almacén
2
Josefina P.
Servicio de Recoleccion de basuras

Elvira C.
Venta de bebidas
4
Elizabeth Gonzalez
Almacen

6

7

8

9

Venta de juegos de azar
10

Venta de ropas
11

12

13

14

15

16

17
